reviewText:
While I attempted to create as clean of an environment as possible, the solution of soap (dawn) and water didn't help in displacing small dirt/dust particles as it theoretically should have. What's worse is that the adhesive side of the screen protector didn't release these particles upon being re-submerged in the solution repeatedly, both full submersion and "rolling" the protector through the tray in an attempt to wash the particles off the film.

Perhaps I got a defective item, perhaps I had not cleaned the area sufficiently (I vacuumed the work surface and wiped it down repeatedly with a clean microfiber cloth).

Ultimately, it appeared that some of the adhesive from the film transferred to the screen, which I am now unable to completely remove. I may try some MEK or acetone, but I hesitate to try anything too strong as I don't want to etch the screen (I'm not sure if it is non-porous enough to resist a strong solvent).

At this point, I can't recommend the product.

reviewText:
This is the second time I've purchased a supposedly-OEM Samsung charger that appears to come from the same knockoff plant in China (this car charger from Amazon, and a wall charger from Ebay). The cable is *almost* the same as the one that came with my Galaxy Tab 2 7" but not quite. Still fits...more or less.

I tested the Ebay wall charger and it doesn't deliver the same power as the charger that came with the tablet (there are apps you can download that show charging details). What's up with that? So now I'm afraid to use this one as it uses the *identical* almost-Samsung USB cable. (Look down the "nose" of the tablet-end plug -- notice how it's narrower?)

Now maybe these really are OEM and Samsung just makes better and subtly different ones that ship with the tablet. But does that seem likely to you? Me neither. I guess I'll be buying accessories straight from Samsung from now on. If the Samsung ones are the same, I'll eat my words and change this review.

Do you remember the Simpsons episode where Homer falls for the "genuine Panaphonics" TV set? I think Amazon has been had...

reviewText:
After picking up the Razr Maxx, I figured that a screen protector might be a good idea.  Did my research and ended up going with the Halo screen protectors. I've never used (nor heard of) the brand before, but I have applied decals and racing stripes to numerous cars in the past, so I wasn't particularly fond of a dry application that this protector used.  However, none of the wet-application protectors offered seemed very enticing this time around, and for $7, I could get THREE!  Figured I would just dive right in.

I'll come right out and say that I am a perfectionist, and ANY little particle underneath the protector just wasn't acceptable to me.  That said, I ended up having to use all 3 of the protectors before I was able to get a 99% flawless application.  If I had a 4th, I would have tried it once more but I was happy with the final product.  There is a video posted on their website that shows the recommended method of application, and I would highly advise checking it out before you dive in.  Unlike wet application covers, you do NOT have the luxury of making full contact with the screen and then squeegeeing out any bubbles and/or imperfections.  While there is some form of very light adhesive on the side contacting the screen, it is mostly held in place by static cling.  My first 2 attempts found a number of micro particles that attached themselves to the adhesive, meaning that they were almost immediately tossed.  Lining up the holes took a great deal of concentration, and if not for a misalignment, the 2nd attempt would have initially worked.

A minor note on installation for those who've never done this before...do it in your bathroom! Close the door, steam up the entire room to an almost uncomfortable level, and do not open the door or turn on a fan. This creates a nearly dust-free environment, as dust will be attracted to the steam, and very little will be left in the air. Wait until the steam settles and move on.

The surface of the protector that is touched feels smoother to slide your fingers on than the screen itself.  Previously, I used a Skinomi Techskin on my Galaxy Nexus, and found the protector to be way too soft...almost to the point that if you ran your fingernail across it, it would make an indentation that would last days.  This protector has a much harder, more ridged feel to it, which is much more appealing.  It doesn't feel rubbery and is as close to 100% transparent as I've ever seen.

Anyhow, quick pros and cons summary for prospect buyers out there:

Pros:
Cost (3 for less than others charge for 1)
Nearly invisible
Very hard and ridged protector
Fingers slide around on screen easily

Cons:
Somewhat frustrating, time consuming dry application
Installation may use more than 1 protector to get it right
Doesn't cover 100% of screen (gaps on all sides)

I can honestly say that I have no real problems with this protector. Yes, it may be a major pain to get it installed perfectly flawless, but with 3 chances for $7, what have you got to lose?  I would buy it again, and just may if I feel that 99% isn't quite good enough for me.  Wouldn't be bad to have some backups on hand either if needed.  Very highly recommended!  I'll update my review if I notice any problems that arise.
summary: For $7, it's tough to find a better protector(s)!

reviewText:
The Nanohold does a great job sticking my iphone to the green/gray LCD display screen in my car securely.  I have been using google map on my iphone and now I can use my iphone screen as GPS.  My car doesn't have a built-in GPS, so my iphone needs to be in the area that is easy for viewing and the current LCD display is the best location for it.  With the Nanohold, my iphone became the LCD display screen and part of my car.  I can use a phone holder, but it can not give the right viewing angle and the holder will take extra space on my dashboard.  Nanohold eliminates the space and viewing angle issues all together.  It also strong enough to hold my iPhone 6 Plus. I was a little worry at first, but I followed instruction and the Nanohold has not failed once.  I saw some bad reviews here for this product, it seems like a few users either really have difficulty following the instructions or they didn't know what they were doing with Nanohold. For me, the instruction is clear and easy to follow. Clean and dry it when it get dirty and put the protective cover on it after you are done using it. Will buy again when I switch another case for my iPhone.

reviewText: Charges my phone fast. I bought this one because it's short and works great with the Anker charger in my car. Can't complain.

This is an amazingly good glass protector for your Galaxy Note 4.
Let's face it if you've shelled out almost 500+ on your phone it pays top protect it.

I opened up the box , which included the screen protector, alcohol wipe, an adhesive dust absorber and a microfibre cloth.

I opened the alcohol wipe, removed the original cellophane from the Phone, then gently rubbed the bare screen. I used the microfibre cloth to dry and then the adhesive dust absorber to remove specks of dust.

Once I was happy the bare screen was completely dust-free, I peeled the back off the screen protector, then aligned the bottom of the screen protector with the home button. I then lowered the screen protector until it decided that it was in place and covered the screen without a bubble in sight!

Fantastic! I had done it! The pedantic may squeal about this, but I'm just so happy I've finally succeeded with a screen protector. It is reassuringly "thick" so I have no doubts it will serve me well.

For the price, you can't fall off, and I recommend to any Galaxy Note 4 purchasers/users as a "must" buy.
Here is my summary of this review.
The first thing you need to know is it fits.
It is ultra clear- you won't know it's there (unless it has done its job and protected your screen)
It's easy to clean
Really easy to apply (just remember to wash your hands and dry really well)
It is bubble free (and from experience I know how big a problem this is even with the more expensive covers)

It's anti-glare which is great for outdoor use.

The super hard covering is said to be explosion proof.

If after reading my review of this product or any of my other reviews and interesting or useful please rate it is as "helpful" or leave a comment. I truly enjoy writing reviews on products that will potentially help someone make an informed decision based on my experience and I also greatly appreciate and I love and hearing feedback so please feel free to let me know if I helped. I make most of my daily purchases here on amazon and base my purchases on reviews of the product from others as well. I know that honest and helpful reviews provide insight to the company and to the purchasers as well.

I received this product for free or at a discounted rate in exchange for product testing and review. I am under no obligation to provide a positive review and received no incentives or rewards for doing so. My aim is to highlight features and drawbacks that I would want to know about as a buyer, not hype the product for the manufacturer to increase sales. My remarks are sincere and true. I work very hard trying to write insightful and thoughtful reviews for each item. My hope is that these reviews are helpful to others. While it is true that many items are received at discounted rates or complimentary, my reviews are completely unbiased as well as honest and are my personal experiences and opinion of the product. Once again, it is just my own opinion and experience.
summary: It's anti-glare which is great for outdoor use.

reviewText:
The reason I got interested with this product is due to the fact that it is only a wall charger and no cables to come with it. Sometimes we just need the wall charger and other times we just want the cables. This time, its just the wall charger that I needed. I attached this to my Qi Wireless charger for my Galaxy S7. The product advertising did not exaggerate the capacity and did not mention about being a fast charger. I'm also aware of this and hoping that I won't be too disappointed when I started using it. The iPhone 6/6S armband is indeed a great product by Belkin. Having been used several such armbands in pasts, this one is certainly much better on several aspects:
- The look and feel of this product is high quality and not really plasticky type. The finish of the case and the plastic in armband is very complimentary to an iPhone.
- The band goes all the way around for a comfortable feel.
- The fabric on the armband behind the plastic clamp for phone is coated with a rubber base to make it waterproof and protect phone from the potential sweat flooding on your arm after a tough workout :).
- The plastic case has a good finish and provide a very good accessibility to the iPhone ports. In some other cases, I had problem accessing these ports since the opening was too tight or close. Not in the Belkin case though.
- For someone who is regular with fitness activities, the case can be left on phone all the time. I do not see that an issue and plan to use the plastic case as the main case for the phone. It does add some bulkiness to device and could be an issue if you prefer to use your phone bare-naked!

Price is a bit on the higher side, however has a high potential to provide the value in terms of continuous protection and functionality to your phone while supporting fitness activities.

reviewText:
Moto G4 Plus White 64GB 4GB RAM

I had a 2nd generation Moto G.  It was great for the price.  Two years after using it I started looking for an upgrade because it was only HSPA+, the battery wasn't lasting as long, and 1GB of RAM was causing some issues.

I looked at several phones including this one (and the G and G Play), the Huawei Honor 5X, LG and Samsung (used flagships and new budget phones), and a used Moto X.  It ultimately came down to the G series and the Huawei.  The Huawei doesn't support T-Mobile fully, so I decided to get the G series.  Around the end of 2016 the price came down to $230 on the G4 Plus and I pulled the trigger.

What I like:
-Battery is really good!  Lasts most of the day.
-4GB of RAM means no issues with programs closing in the background.
-The processor is pretty smooth for a budget phone.
-The phone is pretty much a stock Google Android experience.
-Tons of on-board storage and a SD Card slot

What I don't like:
-I am actually on my second one.  I had to return the first one as I was having issues with Bluetooth disconnecting from my Pebble Classic.  The second one works flawlessly.  I returned it to Amazon so I don't know how Lenovo/Motorola customer service is.
-There is no magnetometer/compass.  My previous one had it.  It is bad if you are walking around doing things like geocaching, but doesn't affect things like car navigation too much.
-There is backlight bleed toward the bottom of the screen.  It was on both of the devices I used but is not super noticeable.
-Plastic on the camera lens (see other).

Other stuff:
-It has a fingerprint reader.  Not as cool as I thought it would be.  It turns on the screen if you touch it with any bit of skin which is kind of annoying.
-Supposedly Nougat is coming.  It was supposed to come Q4 2016, but now it looks like Q1 2017.  I don't really care if it does.  I plan on rooting when the warranty runs out anyway.
-The battery is not removable, but neither was the last one.
-It has a camera.  It isn't the greatest.  It is about what you should expect on a pricier budget phone.  They used plastic on the lens instead of glass on the last one, so I have to be careful not to scratch it.
-There is no NFC or wireless charging, but the last one didn't have that either.
-It has Qualcomm Quick Charge.  It overvolts the USB port to charge the battery faster.  That doesn't sound healthy for long-term battery life, so I just use a regular charger as opposed to the bundled one.  It charges quick enough this way.
-The call quality isn't "HD" or whatever buzzword they are using for the higher frequency range of call audio.
-My old phone had stereo speakers, this only has one.
-It has a headphone jack, but sounds slightly dead compared to my old G.

Overall, I hope the next versions have better quality control and adds back in the magnetometer or I will look at different brands.  If Motorola/Lenovo wants to wow me, put in NFC, a removable battery, and "HD" voice.
summary: Decent.  It has been cost reduced compared to earlier versions. I had to get a replacement one over BT issues.

I purchased a IMP500 battery backup for my iPhone and iTouch before I left on a really long trip a few weeks ago.  I went thru airport security with no issues.  I connected the battery pack when my iTouch battery died and it worked great! I was able to continue watching my movie and get a quick charge at the same time. When other people saw me using it, I became very popular.  I even shared it with a few other iTouch and iPhone users who needed a quick charge on the plane. When I was between flights at the airport terminal, I didn't have to walk around searching for a seat near an electrical outlet to plug in my wall charger. That alone made this purchase worth every cent I paid.

The unit is very small and light, so it is very convenient to carry around.  I leave it in my backpack all of the time. Since the unit has a USB port, I can power up or charge-up any USB device I own.  I like to take my GPS on long trips so I now leave my car and wall charger at home.  I think the quality of this battery pack is very good and the price is very reasonable.  It is the best, longest lasting, and most versatile battery pack on the market. The customer service is excellent; they quickly answered all of the questions I had about the unit before I made the purchase.  I was so satisfied with everything about this product and the company; I purchased a second IMP500 to give as a gift for a friend.  She would give it the same review I did.  This company offers a 30 day money back satisfaction guarantee, so if you don't like it, send it back.  You can't ask for more than that!

reviewText: Original Review: Before I got this case I was using the AmazonBasics Protective TPU Case with Screen Protector for iPhone 5 (Frost) which was nice and sleek but quickly became discolored and did not provide much protection. Since I spent quite a bit on my phone I thought it best to protect it a little bit better. I purchased two of these cases, the blue for my husband and the blush for myself, and so far we are both very pleased with them. Pros: *Great protection against drops. *Easy access to buttons. Easy to push buttons. *Makes phone easier to hold on to. *Comes with built-in screen protector, no more annoying stick-ons! *Reasonably priced. Cons: *The blush is very bright pink. It looked lighter in the picture online, and the hard plastic part looked white online. It's actually gray. The blue case was pretty true to color. *Our audio cables for the car did not work with the OtterBox. They were too thick to fit the inner case. We ended up purchasing two of these Mediabridge 3.5mm Male To 3.5mm Male Stereo Audio Cable - 8 Feet - Step Down Design accommodates iPhone, iTouch, SmartPhone and MP3 cases cables to accommodate. Now we can use with our MP3 input jacks in the car. *These cases do make the phone bulky. *The rubber part does attract a bit of purse and pocket lint, but it's not terrible and it comes off easily. After using these for a day we have decided they are keepers. Update 4-18-13 The case fit loose from the start (the outside rubber part) which I did not notice at first. My husband's case is nice and tight. This got so annoying after awhile that I took the case off and got a different brand. Also, the screen protector over time proved to be horrible, both with attracting smudges and scratches, and it is so large that it's hard to fit it in my pocket.
summary: Loose Fit, Got tired of it

Build quality seems to be great and it came with one short and one long flat micro USB cable. The RAVPower unit can be recharged from empty overnight using my 2.4A charger. It has a 4-LED charge status indicator and continues to charge rapidly with only 1 LED lit. This is not as portable as smaller units, so it's kinda like carrying a book around. Very good looking case, classy.  Fits snug but is extremely hard to get off.  That's one of the stars gone.  It also doesn't have a stand on the back which is the other star gone.

Edit: I realize that others have had issues with the rubber getting discolored on this phone case, but I suppose this just is somewhat of a non issue to me? Mine has hardly gotten discolored and I've had it about 2 years I believe.

The "Spigen Liquid Crystal..." model for absolutely any phone is just the way to go, hands down. Tried it on 4 different types of phones so far now and compared it to other kinds of minimalist cases and even compared it to the Otterbox Commuter cases.

Overall, long story short:
This case beats the pants off of every other phone case, and for a fraction of the price. Go hold an Otterbox Commuter case (not talking about Defender case, that one is for a different target audience) and you get a clunky brick in your pocket and get charged around $30 to totally ruin the look and design of the phone. Then, hold a phone in this case and you get a great design that you can barely see, while giving you a solid grip on the whole phone and stopping any damage from a lot of surprisingly harsh drops (can speak from experience). Even if it falls on its face, the lips is just enough to protect your screen. This case is more like a compliment to the curves of the original design (instead of feeling like you just took a beautiful flower and threw a big brown paper bag over it to keep it safe. Just kills the whole purpose of you liking the phone's aesthetics)

Final words:
It's crazy how well these work to protect the phone while being so minimal, and it looks premium at the same time. At a price point around $10, that is a hard mix of benefits to find without having some tacky looking design that ruins the look of your phone. Most places out there want to charge you $20-50 for a case that is functionally the same exact thing, and yet this design is just as good as any at keeping the sleek and premium look of the phone and showing off your phone's metallic backside.

Pro Tip:
You can also decide to put a picture, or even just press a leaf or something back behind the case to switch things up with your phone case. Give the case even more utility and doesn't cost you anything extra to customize it to your liking.
summary: The best phone case for any phone model, period.

I received this review sample for evaluation. However, my review will be honest and unbiased. Over the years, I've tried a lot of different screen protectors. All of them ended up in the trash. I wasn't fan of protectors until this one, which will go a long way changing my mind. I always had problems aligning them with the phone. Once I got them on, more problems would arise, mainly they interfered with apps functionality. The apps wouldn't work properly until I removed the protector. I really like the iPhone 6 Plus Screen Protector by Maxboost because it was easy to install, and they provided really good instructions, cleaning wipes- -microfiber wet and dry- - and stickers, for alignment and dust removal- - to help you align the protector onto the phone screen. If you're still struggling, they include a QR Code link to an installation video, which I don't think you will need because the instructions are pretty easy to follow.  For those of you who have issues installing protectors- -as do I- -will find these items useful, and will take some of the frustration out of placing it on your phone. It is still a little bit tricky, but not all that hard. It doesn't quite fit over the phone, and it does leave the edges uncovered. This was not a problem for me because I use a phone case that protects the edges. I have used several apps, and they work fine, so no problems there. I really liked the packaging, the item came in a padded envelope. The case in in a really nice sturdy case to protect the protector- -no pun intended- -and the case was inside of a bubble wrap bag! Overall, I like the screen protector, and I am considering buying another one for my iPhone 6 Plus phone, I use for work.

This is my 2nd one of these. The first one broke when I dropped it. The mouth piece popped off and the mic became separated from its wiring. This one looks like a newer revision as it's a bit more sturdy. When working at my desk I prefer a regular handset when using my cell phone. No more putting a call on mute or hold because your chin or ear pushed the button. A great accessory and well worth the small price. Good call clarity both ways.

If you want to protect your phone against drops, bumps, dings, and scratches, and you don't mind the added bulk and lack of "sexiness" then this case is for you. I like that it comes with a belt holster; the case snaps into the belt holster, and the holder can rotate to horizontal or vertical position. This case is good for: -protection against bumps, scrapes, and small drops (ie. from pocket or table top) -screen protection (built-in to case) -minor moisture exposure This case is not good for: -style points; this case is build for function (protection) rather than looks (it looks rugged) -keeping a slender profile; this case bulks up your phone about 3x in thickness -charging stands; I have the Belkin MIXIT Charge and Sync Dock and this case prevents the iPhone 6+ from connecting to the lightning connector. -use with an armband carrier like the Tune Belt Armband for iPhone 6 Plus; it is a really tight fit, but it requires some effort, and the double screen protector (one for the case, one for the armband) reduces screen sensitivity to touch If you are more into the sleek and slender look that matches your iPhone 6+ and don't care much about protection functionality, then skip this case. I like the Tech21 cases sold in the Apple Stores (I haven't tried the Tech21 cases sold on Amazon). Solid 4-star rating. Highly recommended.
summary: Great for overall protection. Not great for style or low profile.

The BlackBerry Leap is a fairly entry level cost smartphone, and is clearly following the trend of on-screen keyboards, now that consumers moved away from individual keys on the device.  The first reaction is that it is yet another smartphone, without being the cutting edge business device that BlackBerry used to be.  This is perhaps not giving the Leap its due, particularly since one of the selling points is the security provided by the device.  I cannot speak to the technical aspects of this security, so I will just take it on faith that this is a secure device, particularly considering the low cost.

As a recent smartphone adopter, I struggled with the iPhone vs. android decision, and ended up with the iPhone.  This review is from the perspective of an iPhone user.  All told, the BlackBerry Leap doesn't make me regret the iPhone choice.

Tactile: The Leap feels pretty good, about the same weight as my iPhone 6.  The screen is clear and bright, although images don't seem quite as sharp.  I wish the corners were rounded a bit more, as this didn't feel very ergonomic.

Cameras:  The main (away) camera is very solid.  It takes good, crisp pictures.  The front facing camera is simply OK, but will provide a slightly grainier image for selfies, etc.  The iPhone camera has a greater variety of functions.

Data Storage:  Equipped with a minimal 16 GB storage, the Leap makes expanded memory mandatory.  Fortunately, with MicroSD, you can supplement it.  My iPhone has more storage, but is not expandable, and the Leap can potentially expand to provide more storage than my iPhone.

Battery Life:  Substantially longer for the Leap.  A better, more efficient battery.

Phone functions:  It does them just fine.  You won't be disappointed or delighted in this aspect.

Apps:  Comes loaded with Amazon Apps, and has a good selection of apps for use.  The pre-loaded apps are acceptable, but not great, particularly when contrasted with those on an iPhone.  Both come with map and alarm clock functions, but the Leap versions just aren't as advanced.

All told, there is nothing particularly wrong with the BlackBerry Leap.  It will work just fine, and has a superior battery.  The price is very good.  But use just feels lacking, and the overall impression is that BlackBerry is playing catchup with the other smartphones, and still has a good ways to go.
summary: As an entry level, it's not bad, but not great

reviewText: great perfect
Very fast delivery. Item was exactly how it was described.

This is actually the third Z3 that I purchased in my search for the perfect unit, and it has satisfied greatly. The Z3 is a great phone but is plagued by some QC issues and terrible customer support. Rather than deal with Sony, I elected to buy through Amazon. Unfortunately, the first model did not pass the waterproof pressure test, and the second's back cracked overnight for no apparent reason (a documented fault).

I made the conscious decision to buy this one used not just to save money, but also because I thought that if this phone was previously used and is still in excellent condition, then its possible that it has avoided the problems that a lot of other customers reported in the first few days of using this phone. This has seemed to hold true as I have had zero issues with my unit so far.

The phone is theoretically very well-constructed with perfectly bonded metal, glass, and vinyl corners (to absorb drops). For such a seemingly fragile device, it performed surprisingly well in a drop test I found on the internet where the guy had to stand on a bench with the phone above his head to cause damage to the phone. Of course, that may have been an exceptional unit, but it was a fairly reassuring example. I actually use a wrist strap for piece of mind, and I have grown to love this advantage; I can feel safe while also using no protection or case at all on my phone, something I will probably never do with any other handset. I did have to cut a paper clip into a hook in order to help push the wrist strap through the provided hole, but it was worth the effort and I did not damage the phone.

Region/Software Info:

My particular unit was an unlocked device originally from the carrier TIM in Italy. The phone was reset 4.4.4 KitKat and I had no problem selecting English from the first screen in setup. To my dismay, the phone is loaded with a few megabytes' worth of TIM apps that I quickly disabled in App Info as soon as I saw them; some can even be uninstalled. In order to enable mobile Internet Data, I had to first connect to wifi and use the "Download Internet/MMS settings" option to get the right Access Point Names for T-Mobile in the US. After installing Nova Launcher, I have a very clean Android experience, even after coming from a Nexus 4 as my last phone. Upgrading to Lollipop through Sony Update center worked fairly well; the only problem is that with so much bloatware, the "optimizing apps" stage of software updates took quite a while. I recommend factory resetting after completing the software updates to avoid some of the battery life/speaker issues that some Z3 owners reported after upgrading to 5.0.2.

My phone is delightfully waterproof, but I tested this first by typing in *#*#SERVICE#*#* into the phone dialpad and selecting the pressure sensor. With all flaps closed, a waterproof phone's internal pressure will rise when lightly pinched between the fingers; this was the test that my first unit failed. If the speakers of this phone get wet, they will sound very quiet and slightly raspy until they are properly dried out again; I don't think this is a Sony problem as much as it is a consequence of the speaker covers being, well, wet. There is a touch-block "Small App" available in the Android multitasking menu that can disable unwanted touches from water contacting the screen.

Unhindered, the stereo speakers are very loud and vibrate the phone with every beat when maxed out. The screen is extremely bright, but the white balance is notoriously on the cold side, with whites nearly 10,000 K (normal whites are around 6500 K). White balance is easily adjusted in the Display menu, but doing so will drop the brightness very slightly. Its still no issue to see in daylight, however.

Speaking of colors, the camera suffers notoriously from the same blue-tint in almost all shooting modes. I find myself using Manual Mode and adjusting the white balance for nearly every photo because the default settings are simply way too far off the warmth of real life. Other than that, there is plenty of detail in the back camera and it is overall excellent provided that you have the patience to adjust a few settings. I was looking for a great camera when I bought this phone; it is overshadowed by the LG G4 and Galaxy S6 by about 10%, but I would say that waterproofing is obviously unparalleled by any other phone with an equal or better camera. The front camera, however, is grainy and pastes faces. It is only 2.2 megapixels; this should be vastly improved in the Z3+ model that will be released later this year.

Call quality is excellent provided that a good signal is available. I use my phone on T-mobile so I have never really experienced great coverage but this phone has rarely let me down. However, I work in a large building with spotty reception; if I leave the cellular radio on, the phone will drain battery fairly rapidly as it stays awake trying to find a signal. Putting my phone on Airplane mode and reenabling Wifi and Bluetooth give me back the great battery life that this phone is renowned for. I often put my phone down at the end of a 16-hour day with around 45 to 50% battery remaining; leaving it unplugged will drain about 5% overnight. This phone can easily stretch to two-days' use, especially if it is turned off when you are asleep.

Sony makes great devices with plenty of potential and I'm glad I gave them a shot this time. It's a shame that they do not market their phones here as I'm sure they would be a hit if more people knew names other than Samsung and Apple. To me, this phone is the only one that fits my purposes in having a great camera, great battery life, great camera, and WATERPROOFING. If something does indeed go wrong, I will probably get an S6 next, but I will sorely miss the waterproofing, stereo speakers, battery life, wrist strap... actually, I might even give the Z3 one last chance!
summary: Could buying used actually be better than new in the case of the Z3?

reviewText: Average quality

I was a little skeptical at first about a screen protector that used a liquid solution, but I decided to go with this protector anyways, and I was pleasantly surprised. Although the directions were not very descriptive, it was relatively easy to prep and apply the screen protector.

I had read a lot about why the directions ask you to turn off your phone before applying the protector, and it turns out that apparently the liquid solution could seep into the phone and cause electrical damage. This is not something to worry about if you do what the directions say. I left my phone off overnight (8+ hours) and it was fine in the morning.

Also in the directions, it says that microbubbles, shines, etc. will go away within 2 to 3 days, and this is completely true. When I woke up to check my phone, there were several large bubbles under the protector, but those started to disappear within a day or so and now (about a week later) there are zero bubbles or marks of any kind. You would never know there was a protector on the screen.

In conclusion, this is arguably one of the best if not the best screen protector available for this phone. It's easy to apply, looks and feels nice, and its self-healing qualities make sure that it will not scratch!
summary: The first and last screen protector I will every buy for my phone

This phone is an amazing value.  It features excellent build quality and a great no contract price.  I happen to have a contract with AT&T and I simply put my sim card in this phone and I was up and running.  It doesn't do LTE speeds, but the faux 4G is good enough.

Windows Phone gets a bad rap for lack of apps, and in some cases it is true.  There is no Google support, so if you use Google Voice, you have to do it in the browser.  Gmail can be checked with the built-in email client.  Other than the lack of Google support, most of the big name apps I use are there.  I'm missing Nest, but I can also do that in the browser.

If you want to, you can pin webpages, such as Google Voice or Nest to the Start screen and they essentially act as apps (albeit in the browser).

This phone is fast enough.  It isn't lacking in speed, as Windows Phone is seemingly optimized for Microsoft's minimum requirements.  You'll see it repeated in tech blogs and videos, and it is true.  Windows Phone feels the same no matter if you are on a 1Ghz dual-core processor (like this phone) or the more expensive models, which are 1.5 Ghz dual-core.  The new 1520 is a quad-core 2.2Ghz.  It will be interesting to see if a quad-core 2.2 Ghz processor makes a difference.

Overall, I am pleasantly surprised by the entire package here.  It has enough speed, a very nice screen, and (mostly) all of the apps I use for an incredible price.  It also feels very comfortable in-hand.  If you are curious about Windows Phone, this is the perfect phone.  If you are on a budget, this is the perfect phone.  If you need a backup phone, this is the perfect phone.  No wonder this phone owns about 30% of the Windows Phone market (at the time of this writing).

I am into photography, so with whatever camera I have handy I shoot pictures. My smart phone is always with me, so this seems like a natural choice. I like shooting creatively, and this little kit gives me that opportunity to do that. I installed the case on a Samsung Galaxy S3 SGH-i747, and the case fit perfectly.

The lenses attach easily, and to my amazement take great pictures. The fish eye is my favorite, macro next, and then the wide angle. Just to give you a heads up, the wide angle has left handed threads, the macro lens has right handed threads. These two lenses are screwed together to make up the wide angle lens so when you screw on the combo, as the macro tightens, the wide angle portion starts to loosen. Personally I think this is pretty clever. With this combo, you now have a bigger lens that's easier to handle to screw on to the case.

It's amazing how close I can get to the subject with the fish eye and still capture the full image. If you have a phone that this will work with and you like taking pictures, then this is a must have.

Now people complaining about it not being water proof it looks legit. I may have not tested this but with the rubber layer and the screen protector on the top it seals the phone very well. I'm sure with enough exposure some could get in but I feel safe with some splashes.

Now with the good comes some bad. First of all the grips on the bad are too small. The kickstand on the back when folded is too big and it rocks around and can easily slide on any surface. I decided to just take this off and hope I don't get it wet as the screen protector combined with the rubber seals with the top plastic piece to prevent dust and water.
Despite this i am overly satisfied with this product and am at peace knowing it will protect my S4 from any type of drop.

PROS:
Combines an iPod/iPhone (30-pin) charging dock with a USB charge port and AC outlet
Wide, stable base
AC extension outlet and USB charge port work perfectly

CONS:
iPhone not always reliably secured/charging in dock
Very large footprint
The dock obscures most of the home button, making it inaccessible when it is in the dock
No LED charge indicator

The RCA PCHSTAB1R 30-Pin Charging Dock is definitely a great concept item.  It combines a charging base for your iPhone4S/iPod 4th generation (or below) and also has a handy AC extension outlet and a USB charge port to boot.  In this world of expanding technology, a device like this is ideal for me: I can charge my work iPhone4, charge my personal flip phone, and plug in an extension set for my home telephone all on my night table and using only a single device.  This sure beats having three cords dangling by my bedside and the need for jury rigging the dual outlet so I can plug in three devices.  In concept it's good.  Sadly, the iPhone does not sit securely in the dock and therefore doesn't always charge reliably.

The device is simply packaged with an insert that is supposed to ensure a good fit for an iPod or older iPhone.  The device is larger than you might think.  It's base is about 5 3/4 inches wide and 3 1/4 inches wide in the middle.  It tapers to about 4 inches in width as it rises up to 2 inches high.  This isn't a small and wimpy device.  It will take up a little desk or night table real estate. The unit also has a little heft to it, something that I think makes a lot of sense: it is sure on its four rubber feet and will not easily tip over or slip. On the back you have an AC extension outlet with a ground and a single USB port for charging.  If the RCA guys really wanted to impress, they might have put two USB ports on the back--there is surely enough room--but this is a minor issue.

The iPhone or iPod is simply inserted in a well on the top of the dock.  Another minor issue: the home button is obscured by the upper lip of the dock.  Granted, this is not a dock/speaker type of device, but if the well were simply shallower, the button would be accessible.

The major problem with this device is that the iPhone dose not 'click' securely into place, as it does when you connect its usual 30 pin connector.  I tried this with the iPhone in the minimalist, Incipio rubber case that I use and with the iPhone out of the case.  I tried using the insert and adjusting the backrest on the insert, still no luck. If I press the iPhone in place (with or without the rubber case) I get that satisfying beep and the screen flashes on.  Still, if I wobble the iPhone just a bit, the battery icon fluctuates between charging and not charging. You have to jimmy the iPhone a bit and make sure that the battery icon shows the lightning bolt to ensure that the thing is charging.  The first night I used this, I placed the phone in the dock and went to sleep.  In the morning, I realized the iPhone had slipped and didn't charge overnight.  I have tried the dock with and without the supplied insert and with and without the case on--it doesn't seem to make a difference.  The phone will definitely charge in this dock; however, the phone is still able to slip out of place easily if I bang the night table.  It would be nice if the device had an LED on the front to indicate whether the iPhone was charging or not.

Most nights, I have been using the dock, but if I want to ensure a charge or will have the phone plugged in longer than one night, I simply use a 30 pin cord and plug the iPhone into the USB charge port on the back.  This works just fine, but it negates the need for having this kind of dock.

Once again, this is a great concept, but the implementation is less than stellar.  The device works after a fashion, but because the iPhone can slip out if you are not extra careful, I am giving this only three stars.
summary: Nice idea, not always so reliable

The only other excellent phone mount concept that I have seen is the one that attaches to your vent, but many would prefer to use their vent for what it is intended... keeping you cool/warm. The Mountek nGroove provides an alternate method of using your CD slot, which arguably is going the way of the cassette deck with MP3s, music apps, and satellite radio taking over. The mount basically slides slightly into your CD slot and the screwing/tightening mechanism allows you to tighten the fit so the mount doesn't fall out. I thought this was an excellently thought out concept.

Now to the negatives, which there are 2. First and most importantly, there are some car sound systems that this WILL NOT work well with. For example, my Accord's sound system has a the power/volume knob in the center, right below the the mount. As a result, the screwing/tightening mechanism basically pushes/covers the power/volume knob of the system. It my car, it actually pushes on the knob and makes the system unusable. So my suggestion is to look right below the center of your CD slot and see if the screwing mechanism will cause some issue with your system. My wife has her knob to the left side of the CD slot, so it worked perfectly for her.

Secondly, the eject mechanism is just really difficult to manage. My vent mount has two buttons on each side of the lower part that you simply just pinch/press. That is very easy and user-friendly. This mount, on the other hand, has one button on the top of it that you have to press to release the side grips. I find the button to be quite annoying to manage, because you MUST use two hands to get the phone released. Two hands??? This is silly to me, given how easy it was to release my phone from the vent mount that I used with one hand.
summary: Unique design but beware of compatibility...

This LINKON external battery charger has a feature that I wish all power banks had -- a digital readout showing how much charge is left in the battery, and it tracks the level as you charge it and as you use it to charge other devices. You will not be surprised by an empty backup battery with this one.

This backup battery has a stylish pink & white design, seems well constructed (states that it contains a Samsung 'Grade A' cell), and is of a very convenient and portable size. It is an easy carry in your purse, jacket pocket or back-pack. With its stated 1.0 amp output, this battery charged our phones at a rate typical of the performance we get from wall outlet charger... but only when using our phone's USB power cable to charge the phone.

The battery comes with a micro USB cable and adapters for Apple lightning cable and other notebook fittings. However, the performance we attained when using the supplied cable was not good... at best it charged our HTC Droid DNA at about 1/2% per minute or 30% in an hour. Additionally, we found the transfer drain to be large; roughly, boosting the DNA's charge up 30% used up about 45% of the LINKON battery's capacity. Since the DNA has a 2020mAh battery and this LINKON unit is advertized as 3000mAh, something seemed not quite right there. Additionally, the battery got very warm while charging the phone (warm, but not overly hot).

However, we solved the issue fairly easily by switching to using the DNA's USB power cable. Both the charge rate and efficiency improved significantly to a level in line with expectations.

This battery is nice looking and conveniently sized, and the digital readout makes it simple and fun to use. LINKON's warranty coverage seems very strong, stated as "14 day money back guarantee no questions asked if you are not happy with our product plus 12 month warranty for total peace of mind", so if an issue arises before that period expires I will return here to update the review We did receive this unit gratis from the manufacturer, and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.

Portable, stylish and, when using your own power cable, did the job to meet our expectations. If you are looking for a battery pack of this size, great style and capacity, for use as I have described above, then I would say give this unit a try.  If it does not meet your expectations, you have their good guarantee and warranty to rely on.

Go for it.
summary: LINKON Portable Power Bank Backup Battery - 1.0A Output - Pink - Digital readout is great - Works best with phone's USB cable

reviewText: great

Have only used it a few days, so I'm leaving my initial impressions.
The size is perfect.  Most battery cases protrude well below and above the standard case.  The iPhone plus is huge to begin with, to anything that adds to it's height will be noticeable.  This case adds very little to the height of your phone, same as a regular thick case would.  The battery is stored in the back of the case, so it does impact the thickness a tad.  Not much, and again, not much more than a standard case would.  The texture is smooth, which I'm not a fan off.  It makes it slick and difficult to hold.  My grippy case was better in this respect.

Once you slide it in, it's good to go.  There's one button on the back and some lights that will indicate how much charge is left.  I noticed that some lightning cables fit better than others.  Third party cables may be thicker and will not fit as well.  The pass through technology is wonky and doesn't has to be be fiddled with to get a good fit.  If you plug in the cable, your phone will charge first, and when it's topped off, then the case will charge.  When using the device to play music through the usb/lighting cable, it was very sensitive, and would give me an error if I moved it too much.  Also, I could not charge the phone in the case with my lightning cable plugged into the computers USB port.  I think the power draw was too small.  I could only consistently charge it by plugging into a wall outlet.  Still despite all this I really like the product and give it a solid 4 stars.
summary: Compact battery case for a decent price

reviewText: What an amazing mount! This is the best mount I have ever used. The phone stays secure in place and won't fall out as it has with other mounts. Normally air vent mounts block the air coming through, but this is not an issues with this mount. As you can see in the video, there is no air being blocked. You have a lot of flexibility with the swivel and 306 degree rotation. Most importantly the phone will be at eye level which is safer when you drive. You will notice that my phone was placed higher then normal. This is because I have the Google Nexus 6P phone which has buttons on the side of the phone. It is best to mount the phone in the middle if you don't have buttons in the middle. I received the mount in exchange for my review.

Micro-suction tape is a wonderful invention! This super gel pad is actually a tape made of acrylic foam with a surface of millions of microscopic craters. Individually, the little craters have minimal suction, but together the entire surface of craters has major suction. This ring holder/stand has a rectangle of this tape on the back. It is meant to be mounted on very flat surfaces.

The square is 1 3/8 x 1 9/16.  The inside ring diameter is hard to describe, as it is a bit oval, with about 1 one way, and 7/8 the other way.  The ring swivels 360 degrees and will stay in place at any angle.

Right now I have this attached to my air card (wireless adapter) so I can hang it from one of several Command hooks that I have anchored in high positions around several windows so I can get the best reception.  With the help of a hook, you could hang anything, as long as it has a flat surface and weighs less than four pounds.  And of course, you can use it as a stand for a small device, or hang a device from your finger.  Lots of uses.

Do I think my devices are vulnerable to falling off of this small suction plate? NO. Do I think the stand comes un-stuck too easily? NO. Do I use common sense when mounting this stand? YES. What I'm trying to get across to you is this: Its surface needs to be totally clean and the surface you are sticking it on needs to be very clean.  The little craters in the foam can fill up with dust and dirt. I run an alcohol wipe over the surface where I want to mount the stand to remove whatever particles and grime might be there, make sure it's dry, then I stick the stand in place. Would I eat a burger and fries, while I'm holding my phone, then immediately stick the phone to the tape? Duh....NO.

It is meant to hold tightly, but can be removed easily by using a real tough thumb nail or a stiff credit card to get under a corner of it.  Dont use a screw driver or anything metal, as it can scratch the surface of your device.  Then pull slowly and the little suction craters will release.  What if it does get dirty and stop sticking perfectly well? Easy to clean! I like to use a wet paper towel, then let it dry thoroughly.

All in all this is a nice looking little stand with a minimalist style to it. It works very well. And I trust the micro-suction tape to hold tight and am not afraid to hang my devices from it seven feet above the floor.

**I received a free sample product from RingStand.
summary: I trust this "super gel pad" micro-suction tape

reviewText:
First what I love: The color purple looks great and is how I expected it to look. The phone passed the water test and did not leak at all. I am able to take photos and make voice calls normally, the case does not disturb the use of these features. The phone includes a cleaning cloth and a lanyard which I have never seen to be included with a waterproof case before. There is also a headphone jack adapter.

What I didn't like: The case is very hard to put on and take off. To me that really isn't a big negative because the case fits well and is protective so I do not plan to take it off and on very often. The reason for deducting a star is that the sound on/off switch does not work with this case. With the case off I can flip the switch and see that it moves but for some reason it does not move my phone's sound switch so I am unable to operate this feature of my phone.

I was provided this case for product review and these are my opinions based on my experience.

reviewText:
This is a thin piece of plastic that serves more as a "skin" than a case. It does not provide any cushioning and little structure support. You can feel the seam all around the side where the machine that made it joined two smaller pieces of plastic. Part of owning an iPhone 6 plus is having a wonderful world-class phone. Putting this case over it is like adding vinyl seat covers to your new BMW. Does it offer some protection to the phone? Yes. Is it small and non-bulky? Yes. Does it deserve the reviews that have been posted about it? I don't think so. I don't usually write reviews, but feel like I was misled by all the positive reviews here and wanted to lay down some truth.

Update 5/9/2015: I've been using this for the last six months. I've dropped the phone a few times and it was been very minimally protected by this "case". Further, the clear case has turned yellowish and ugly, and the tinted color remains after washing it. Finally, due to daily use and poor materials, the case has stretched a bit and now easily falls off the iPhone. I've finally purchased a different case, the Spigen Slim Armor, and am very happy with it.
summary: flimsy and you can feel the seams

The colors that these styluses come in are so bright and the aluminum surface holds up well without scratching easily. Because the aluminum is a matte color, finger prints don't show up at all. It's a very nice quality and beautifully colored full sized stylus that will fit anywhere you can keep something the size of a pen.

reviewText:
Pros:
1. Fair price

3. Looks like it will protect your phone, if dropped

5. Has a small lip on top, so your screen will never hit the surface, if you place your phone screen-side down.
6. Cutouts are big enough for the charging cable, headphones, and camera.
7. Fits the phone pretty well, overall (except for the side buttons - see Con #1)

Cons:
1. Case is loose, where the side buttons are.  You have to press the case pretty hard to use the buttons.
2. The clear back is getting pretty scratched up.  I've had it about a week now, - I think in a few months, it may not be clear in certain spots anymore...
3. The case is a little thick for my taste.  I wish it was a little thinner...
4. The plastic is a really shiny.
5. Seems unecessarily thick where the camera is.  So, when you place the phone down, it doesn't lie flat on the table.  It can rock, if you push down on the corners/sides.

In short - this case works for now.  Meanwhile, I am still looking for a different case, or even a nice bumper fot this phone.  My previous phone is the OnePlus One phone, and I LOVED my Diztronic case.  Too bad they don't make a case for this phone....

reviewText: I was provided a 9to5Cables Dual USB 3.1A 15W Travel Wall Charger for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found. What You Should Know Before You Buy: Has two ports (a 2.1 Amp Apple Port and a 1 Amp Universal Port) that provide a total output of 3.1 Amps. Has a large enough output capacity to provide fast charging speeds when charging multiple devices simultaneously. Very fast charging speeds when charging an iPhone 5 and an iPad 2 at the same time. Compact and has folding prongs for travel. This wall charger comes in Black or White to match your personal preference. Detailed Review: Look - The product came in a professional looking box with a picture and product information on it. Inside the box was only the wall charger in a form fitting plastic insert to protect it. This is a fairly small, high powered dual port wall charger. It measures 2.5" x 2" x 1". It has two USB ports and provides a total output of 3.1 Amps. It has an Apple designated port producing 2.1 Amps and a Universal port producing 1 Amp. It also has an blue power indicator light between the two ports. The prongs fold into the body of the charger for storage and travel. It appears to have a very good build quality. Use and Performance - I plugged it into a wall outlet and did some testing to see how the wall charger handles simultaneous charging. I took my iPhone 5 that had 39% charge and my iPad 2 that had 66% charge and charged them simultaneously. I plugged the iPad into the 2A Apple port and the iPhone into the 1A Universal port. After 10 minutes, the iPhone charge increased to 49% and the iPad increased to 69%. After 20 minutes, the iPhone charge increased to 59% and the iPad increased to 73%. After 30 minutes, the iPhone charge increased to 68% and the iPad increased to 76%. The iPhone charged at about 1% per minute and the iPad charged at better than 3% per 10 minutes. Some great results while charging two Apple products simultaneously. It did give off some heat when charging, but not too much. Conclusion: Overall, this is a great travel wall charger at this price point ($13 at the time of this review). It has a large output capacity that charges multiple devices very fast. On top of that it is small and compact with folding prongs for storage and travel. If you are looking for an inexpensive dual port wall charger, the 9to5Cables Dual USB Travel Wall Charger is one to try. Highly Recommended!
summary: What You Should Know Before You Buy!

reviewText:
At 12 oz. and 5.8/2.8/0.94" comes near the limits of portability if you are using it to fuel up your cell phone or tablet but its size and weight are very much justified by the 15000mAh Li-ion batterry that should easily charge a phone several times and should be sufficient for at least one full charge on most tablets. For example, an iPad 3 battery capacity is 11560mAh while in iPad Mini 2G has 6471mAh.

The slab-shaped battery pack has a nice brush steel finish and comes with a couple of extra perks: there's an illuminated digital display showing you the amount of charge stored as a percentage. If you double-click the power button you turn on a one-LED light which may come handy.

Charging is done through the 1A and 2.1A USB ports and you can use the provided cable if you wish..

The LP150X can be charged through a micro USB port (cable provided) but you need your own charger.

I found no fault with the device. It's a good pick if 'capacity' is a requirement and its size and weight are not an issue.

*** [sample provided for an honest review]

I have owned Otterbox Commuter cases for my last few phones, which included a BlackBerry and an Android phone. I have always liked the Commuter cases, but when I upgraded to the iPhone 5 last October I didn't initially buy a case for the phone because I liked the slimness of the phone and felt that the phone itself seemed durable enough to withstand daily use. I tend to carry my phone in my pocket -- either the front pocket of my jeans or the jacket pocket in my suit -- and generally this has been fine. No, the world does not come crashing down if you carry an iPhone without a case. Actually, as a guy (not a lady with a purse), it can be quite enjoyable to carry and use a well-built metal device that is slim enough to fit in any pocket without creating a bulge. I have a leather pouch (Mujjo) that I sometimes put the phone into depending on what kind of clothes I'm wearing or if I'm near water, but generally I have been caseless since October and the phone has not been damaged in any way that I can tell (and I tend to notice these things).

After a few near-misses last month where I almost dropped the phone (but didn't), I decided that it might be good to go back to using a case, and because I like Otterbox I immediately gravitated toward the Commuters. But the Commuter case is thick enough that it removes much of the reason I have been loving the iPhone 5 - its form factor. I also found that some of its selling points over other cases -- like port covers and "hybrid" construction -- don't actually matter to me. That was why I decided to try the Reflex case.

The Reflex case fits the phone very well but does not add much thickness to the phone at all. I have been able to carry the phone in my pocket as usual without noticing any significant difference. Like the Commuter case, it contains parts made of both rubber and hard plastic which are designed to absorb shocks and bumps. Because it is not a hybrid case with a full rubber interior, it will not absorb quite as much abuse as a Commuter case would, but it also is much thinner and lighter. It's also quite easy to get on and off and, as far as I can tell, does not damage the phone in the process. This is important to me because there are times when I don't want to use the case, or I want to use a different case, like a Mophie extended battery pack. The Reflex is very well designed around the edges and ports of the phone and does not affect use. It does have a slight "lip" around the screen which is useful for preventing screen damage in the event of a fall (great design from past experience), but this does not affect typing on the device.

Some other reviewers have reported difficulty connecting the standard Lightning plugs and chargers to the bottom of the phone; I have not experienced this problem at all. I connect the phone every day in the car and every night at home and never have difficulty.

Some other reviewers have also reported problems with the "slider" design of the case coming apart occasionally; I have not experienced this problem either, but time will tell.

I also like the look of the case on my black iPhone 5. One of the reasons I wanted a case for my phone was to make it stand out from all the other corporate iPhones around me. Mission accomplished there.  Most of the color schemes sold on Amazon -- including the "Radiate" one that I picked -- are cool but rugged looking. I do wish that the semi-transparent back of the case did not have as much writing on it (patents, etc.) but that's a minor gripe. I also wish that the button covers for the lock and volume buttons were not so stiff, but this is also not a big problem.

Overall I think this is a great case for someone looking for protection almost as good as the Commuter case while still retaining most of the thinness of the iPhone's naked design.

reviewText:
Epic 4g Touch is one of a new breed of "super" phones. Dual core SoC processors. The features and performance that this phone has gives it a seamless and smooth flow of operation. This phone has not locked up on me once since I got it a week ago. 10 programs open, no lag. It is very light to a point where it worries me that if I drop it it may break. I didn't want to take any chances so I went ahead and bought one of those TPU matte cases and now it has a very nice balanced weigh to it.

The 4.5 inch is crisp and very bright. Using it out in the sun is no problem either because of the Super AMOLD display. All of the App icons are nicely sized to fit the large screen.

One thing that I have noticed is that accessory vendors are slow to develope accessories for the Epic Touch. May be in a few months this might be the case but for now be prepared for some slim pickings when it comes to accessories with this phone.

Reception is great and calls come in clear. People on the other end also say the same.

Over all I am very happy with this phone.

This is a great case for my android phone. I have used my old one till it has wore out. Have never lost phone out of case or have had any damage to the phone. I ordered 2 this time so I could have one for work and one for going out. I like the soft case much better then bulky hard cases.

I love everything except the color, which is much darker than in the picture. It's more like a blue-black than a navy. This one came with a clear decal to stick to your apple logo so it isn't scratched through the cutout on the back. The plastic also has a rubberized feel to it, which is different from previous Ringke cases I've owned.

I'm a huge fan of Ringke's SLIM cases. I've had one for my Samsung Galaxy Nexus, one for my Galaxy S4, and now one for my iPhone 5S. They always fit perfectly and the plastics feel of a better quality than other cases I've bought from manufacturers like elago (cheap, cheap, and super cheap) and caseology (good, but not great). As I said, other than the color, I am very happy with it.  Very high quality and consistent with what I've come to expect from Ringke.

The color, though...:(

reviewText:
It works, but the indoor range, even boosted is very limited. But I did go from 0 bars to 3 bars inside. However, the indoor range (with the range adjusted to max) is only 15-20 feet. Literally, I go from 3 bars to 0 in the space of 2 steps. But its better than missed calls or standing outside to make a call.
It works, bottomline. It could be better for the price. The signal does seem to get easily blocked inside though, so keep things clear around the antenna .
Installation is straight forward. Two screws to an exterior place of your choosing, higher up the better. Comes with plenty of cable. Some fo the other reviews say replace this with a higher qualit and get much better signal....can't say on this. I'm using what came in the kit.
You have to have a place it can come into the house. I use a flat coax to run it in a closed window. Works well.
Exterior receiver so far has been weather proof- no issues there. We'll see how it handles the winter.
Only real negative is the indoor range, turned to max is it still very short range 10-15 foot for best results with no walls, just open air from transmitting antenna to cell phone.
Works with AT&T. Can't say for others, but I see no reason why it wouldn't. Thankfully none of that proprietary garbage.
summary: Decent could be better on indoor range

It is also solid as a rock, which makes it a lot easier when you are tapping buttons on the screen of your phone. I have used this mount to hold my smart phone, as well as a company issued Samsung Tablet, and in both applications, the mount has worked Absolutely Perfectly.

I got a very good price for this mount, but would still consider it worth the money if I had paid up to $35. I have paid that much in the past, for mounts that turned out to be very disappointing.
Its awesome

Getting this case has seriously made my week!  I'm a super big klutz, I drop my phone all the time so it's really important that I have a case to protect it that works well. But here's the thing....I'm as cheap as I am klutzy.  I can't bring myself to pay upwards of $40 to $50 for a phone case.  That just seems ridiculous to me.  So I decided to give this case a shot.  I mean, it says it's shockproof, how awesome is that??

I've had the case for about 4 days now and I love it!  Yes, I've dropped my phone more than once.  No, my phone didn't break.  That's good enough for me!  Oh, and it comes with a screen protector.  The only thing that would be better than a screen protector is a tempered glass protector, but at this price point I can buy a tempered glass protector and still save a TON of money!

Oh, and my favorite part?  That's cool little kickstand on the back.  This allows me to prop my phone up so my music comes out better and I can easily see when I get calls while working.  I received this case at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest, unbiased review and I would totally buy this brand at full price in the future.
summary: Perfect for a klutz like me!

reviewText:
I purchased this for my Nokia Lumia 920 after much research.  Since the Lumia has all of it's buttons (volume, power, camera) on the same side of the phone, I was worried about the arms of the mount pressing in on them.

I wanted a mount that could also be used with a case and it seems that mounts that are made specifically for the lumia 920 have issues if you use a case.  This works great since the arms adjust width-wise.  I use a Speck case.

It is best to use this upside down for the Lumia 920.  While you can use it upside up, you will not have access (or very difficult access) to the power button.  But it works perfectly upside down with access to the power button, and the arms don't press in on any of the other buttons.

The mount itself fits great on the vents in my Mercury Sable (2002) and my Ford Explorer (2002).  The only issue with the Sable is that the 2 mounting clips need to go through these 2 wider openings that surround the finger adjustment on the vent.  But it fits perfectly there like it was made for it.  No issues at all in the Explorer.

The clamps adjust very easily to keep your phone in place.  Press a button and they pop out, releasing your phone instantly. Close them together to adjust to almost any sized phone.  Just need to squeeze a bit hard to get that last click in place to have a solid hold on the Lumia 920.

The tabs that swing out from the top or bottom that your phone rests on, could be a tad bit bigger.  They're there to help keep your phone in place while you clamp the mount to your phone.  Also the clamps are big, much bigger than they need to be.  I suppose if you're using an Otter box or some huge case, it's great.  The slight cushion inside the clamps allow you to press harder to get a nice secure fit to your phone.

I'd give it a 5 star rating if it fit the Lumia perfectly upside-up and closed nicely without having to squeeze as hard as I do to get it to a nice snug fit where I know it's not going anywhere.  But overall, I'd get this mount again. I really like how it clips onto the vents so it's out of the way, not visible on my windshield or dash.  Great mount overall!
Very nice.  Not as bulky as the OtterBox I had for my Iphone.

reviewText: Not bad, but if you buy a new phone that costs several hundred $$, don't be a cheapskate on the case. This case worked great, then dropped screen first onto asphalt parking lot, and the screen broke.. Even with insurance, you have to pay the deductible. This is ok, but there are better choices.

When I got the Droid Razr Maxx I was on the fence about getting a case. I used a similar "gel" type case on my old Droid X for the 1st year I had it but I ended up going naked for the 2nd year I had it and loved the reduced bulk and nicer feel of just touching the phone itself. I decided to try a case at least for a while as the phone would cost a lot of money to replace if I dropped it.

I needed a case for mine and my wife's so I bought 3 of these cases when they had the buy 2 get one free promotion. I got them in white, black and blue. I was pleasantly surprised with them when they came. They are very sharp looking, fit the phone great without adding too much bulk and feel really good in the hand.

You can't tell from the photos really but the part of the case with the Android on it and the sides where your hand would grip it are a matte finish and the rest of it is a gloss finish. The contrast is really attractive and the case has a nice overall grippy feel making it less likely you'll drop the phone. The sides also have textured lines on them to add to the gription (note: gription may not be a word but it should be).

Pros:
-Fits perfect
-Seems like a good balance between protecting the phone while keeping added bulk to a minimum
-Grippy
-Very attractive colors, blue in particular
-Great price for a quality case

Cons:
-I can't really think of any, maybe dust getting behind the clear plastic once in a while?
Excellent product. Practical, small, functional, sharpness of the photos are acceptable and the quality over the price worth buying. 100% Recommended.

Do you plan on running? Do you plan on exercising? Do you plan on sweating? Do you need freedom from wires, mobility, and long battery life?  Then Vic Tsing has the perfect headphones for you - the PBT002B Bluetooth Sport Headphones!  They are powered by an 80 mAh Lithium-ion battery which provides 5 hours of play time with a 2 hour full charge time.  Other great features include the ability to pair 2 devices and IOS Battery Status Display.

Now for the real review part, I have tried these running and lifting weights in the gym.  The comfort level is great.  No problems wearing them til battery dies but I never last that long.  The sound quality is where these shine to me.  For running out doors on a track next to a busy road car noise is a burden but these headphone are loud enough to eliminate all that and more.  I also run 5 miles from an airport and the loud volume of the sound at max volume even drowns that out.  I don't like listening to music that loud but its there if you need it.  I also like the ability to play\pause or skip songs on the fly with the headphone buttons on the right earbud.  Connecting the to my Android phone is a breeze.  The one down side i experienced was in the gym where I left my phone in my gym bag and walked about 15 feet away to a machine and got a little bit of static other than that these are perfect!

Pro's: Great size/ form factor. Weight is a tad heavy, but makes the unit "feel" like quality. The flashlight is good, considering its a secondary feature. The laser pointer is a nice touch. I could take this into a business meeting and no one would know its a backup battery. I tested its charging speed on my IPhone 4S and it took 1hr 30min to charge from 35% to 100%, worthy of note, it only took 1hr to get from 35% to 90%. Have not been able to test how many charges the unit will provide before it needs charging, or if the speed of charge changes with less power in the pack. The usb connectors are quality with no slip whatsoever.

Con's: The button feels kind of cheap. I, personally, would sacrifice the flashlight (or laser pointer) space for a better switch like a toggle or slider. The indicator lights on the top are somewhat confusing. 4 lights, 3 show capacity 4th is if unit is charging something. They're placed together as if they are charge indicators. I would separate the 4th a bit, maybe put above the 3 and center the three left to right. On a user note, I'd change the order of the flashlight and laser pointer in the turn on sequence. reviewText: So far I have not had any charging issues with this charger. It seems to charge everything I plug into quicker than the chargers that came with the devices. As soon as I purchased an iPhone, I knew I had to get something to protect it from my clumsiness, and after looking around at a friends Defender (and realizing how BIG of a case it was) I wanted something smaller, but still able to handle punishment.  So far, the Commuter has fit the bill.

The Commuter consists of 3 parts, a screen protector (applied with an applicator to 'try' to smooth out the bubbles), a silicon sleeve to protect the sides and back from drops and impacts, and frame / metal wrap to keep the silicon sleeve in place.

Overall, the pieces and parts work well to protect the phone from scratches, dings, and most importantly (for me) drops.  I've dropped the phone several times now on hardwood floors (just my lack of coordination) pulling it out of my pocket (3ft) and have seen no signs of damage to the phone.  The screen protector is doing its job, and doesn't seem to easily scratch (the phone sometimes rides around in my pocket with keys, and still looks perfect).  Additionally, since most of the ports are well protected, small splashes haven't seemed to hurt it at all, even though it doesn't claim waterproof abilities.

Another nice thing about this case is that it adds very little in the way of size.  The iPhone is a fairly good sized phone to begin with, but this case is a very small addition and the protection is well worth it.  The buttons are all easy to press with the case on, and the speakers still provide close to the same sound (from what I can tell).

The only reason I've given this a 4 instead of a 5 is because sometimes the case tries to slip from the edges occasionally, and the covers for the ports can sometimes be a pain to get back into place.  Overall though, I can't complain and have been very happy with its level of protection and small size.

Had this phone for over 3 weeks but just had to return it. Let me tell you this phone has a great quality build and great spec's. The overall hardware is incomparable and really stands out in comparison to that of the competition. The 12 megapixel camera takes outstanding pictures and can easily replace a "point and shoot" camera.. Honestly the phone is an honest good buy but the Symbian OS ruines the whole user experience.

I have been an avid Nokia user since the release of the Nokia N95. From there on I have owned the N82, N86 and jumped to the N900 last year. After being spoiled using the Maemo OS found in the N900 I honestly hoped that the Symbian's OS update would catch up and even exceed Maemo which has now evolved into MeeGo thanks to it's partnership with Intel. Sadly Symbian stays way behind and I found myself wanting to throw the phone across the room at times due to the various frustrations it caused.

Constant freezing, long wait time, and constant clicking from one thing to another just to get a task done. I love you Nokia but Android and Apple's iOs have left you behind. I'm only hoping that Nokia's next flagship phone has MeeGo OS as it's software platform and maybe I'll jump back and be the happy customer I once was when owning a Nokia device.

Overall if your looking to own a phone with excellent call quality, outstanding hardware/build and looking to replace your "point and shoot" camera with a phone then go ahead and make your purchase. But if your out looking for a great overall Smartphone then I recommend you look away from anything running Symbian.
