For the price, it should be a great value.  I commend BLU for offering a phone at this price point.  I really wanted to see a low cost option.  Initially my review was one star but I am now changing it to 3 stars.

I ignored the one star reviews about phone rebooting itself constantly.  When I first got it, that's all it did with the AT&T SIM in the phone.  It couldn't charge because it rebooted constantly.

As for ATT, I tried two SIMS, ensured the right IMEI number was registered (remember this has two SIM capability so there are two IMEI numbers).  At the ATT store, we gave up as well.

To save you some hassle, here are some tips:

1. Tech support requires an enormous amount of personal information which is not necessary to troubleshoot this problem.  I can understand email address, maybe a first and last name but why do you need my cell phone number when any contact info would suffice in case we get disconnected?  You are not marketing, stick to troubleshooting my problem
4.  Troubleshooting is simply nothing more than doing a hard reset, instructions available on the web.  By the way, a hard reset through the settings did not work for me.  Technical support did offer an alternative method (below).  However, I have 3 other Windows phones and I knew tech support's instructions were wrong (key sequence).  I also did not receive their email for whatever reason.
1st way to reset:
Go to settings, about, scroll down to reset your phone (easier)
OR
Use the key sequences below:
*Make sure your phone is off.
*Press and hold Volume Down button then power button (together)
*The moment it vibrates, Release the power button till an exclamation sign appears
Now release the Volume Down button.
Now enter the following sequence within a second or two of each other
*Press Volume Up button.
*Press Volume Down button.
*Press Power button.
*Press Volume Down button.
Phone reboots
If you see spinning gears, you have done it correctly.  If not, you screwed something up, start the sequence again (or do it the easy way above :)).

I was ready to ship this back after doing a hard reset (easy way twice and hard way once).  For some reason, I decided to uncheck 3g under cellular.  The moment I did that, it connected to AT&t and all was well.  Or it was just a coincidence, maybe I had to hard reset 3 times.  I checked 3G once again and all is well.  Maybe ATT issue not accepting a 3G connection or just a coincidence.

The phone also updated twice during the process by the way so I have the latest 8.1 release.  Note the hard reset doesn't revert back to previous OS versions so that's good news, it just cleans the data.
Bottom line, I shouldn't have to do all this but if your phone reboots and you still want to keep it, hope this review/troubleshooting helps.

If your phone works out of the box, you were luckier than I.

Now the phone has been working for 8 hours with no problems.  I desperately need a storage card as my daughter already decided to load 1GB of apps on it so 116MB available, oops.  If the phone is dependable, I will up the stars to 4 or even 5 due to its value.

As for Windows OS, I like it but this review is for the phone only.

Update:  6/22/15.  Phone is now rebooting on its own and inoperable for the most part.  I tried a hard reset but screen freezes, it reboots, it's a mess.  Still under warranty.  Note you must pay for shipping and it takes 10-15 days for BLU to assess and give you options.  Will update but that's a long time without a phone so it's a bummer that they don't cross ship.

Update 7/9/15:  They sent me a refurbished phone, took about 2 weeks for the end to end exchange.  Seems to be working ok.
summary: it should be a great value. I commend BLU for offering a phone ...

reviewText: Fits just right and easy to put on.

Please note: I received a free sample for an evaluation and honest review.

Nowadays, USB chargers come in all sorts of shapes, sizes, number of ports, and current capabilities. Some have external cords, and others (like this charger) plug directly into an outlet. If you're looking for a USB charger, you've got a lot of choices. :) Only you know the best set of specs for your needs, so I'll just try to describe what I think are the relevant qualities of this model.

This is essentially identical to another charger that I recently reviewed (except that one is white) - which is great because both are quite nice.  First, it's very well made. Rock solid with no loose parts or rattles at all. The retractable plug snaps firmly into place in both the open and closed position, and it's not difficult to move. The USB ports are sized properly so that cables plug in with ease but are not wobbly or loose inside.

The whole unit has an Apple-ish look and feel to it. Well, old school Apple when they offered some glossy black plastic units, that is. :)  It just has that same quality feel that my Apple gear has.

Personally, I really like highly compact units like this because I think that they are great for travel. Assuming that wherever you are staying has a power outlet readily available, that is. Luckily, most hotels seems to have one or more power outlets exposed on top of a desk (such as the two on the base of a table lamp at the hotel that I stayed in last week). If you stay somewhere in which the outlets are further out of reach, you'd probably benefit from a different charger that comes with a power cord unless you get an extension cord for this.

Two outlets is perfect for me because I tend to take a phone and a tablet with me, and this can charge both with ease. Both ports can handle up to 2.4A, which is beyond what I need on any of my phones or tablets.

I have nothing bad at all to say about this charger - I think that it's a great product. If it meets your needs for number of ports, current capability, and outlet accessibility, I recommend it.
summary: Fantastic little charger that is great for travel or home

reviewText:
Just purchased my 4th Jawbone prime.  I had the Jawbone II before that.  This is an all around good headset, but the multiple size ear fittings are what make it great for me.  I tried a lot of other bluetooth headsets before finding the jawbone, it was the first one that I could actually get to fit my ear.  It stays put without even having to use the ear loop.  Of course, fit is entirely subjective.  You have to try it on to see if it's going to work for you, just like a pair of shoes.

In other categories, the Jawbone does well.  Volume output is good, I never have an accidental hangup.  Mic pickup is excellent.  Connection with my phone is pretty consistent.  Really, no complaints on performance.

My one and only gripe is the longevity.  Like I said, this is my 4th Prime.  The 3 previous ones have all suddenly died after 6 to 12 months of use.  Granted, I use it a ton.  But it's not the battery wearing out, the charge stays consistent even after up to a year of use.  But then the time comes, like this morning, where something inside the Jawbone just dies and it won't come on anymore.  This was a bigger gripe back when you had to pay $90 for one, now that they are only ~$30 it's hard to complain too much.....

I'll keep buying and using these because they work perfectly for me, though I get irritated with the sudden death, it's the best bluetooth I've found.  And an incredible deal at the price.  And since other bluetooths I've owned have useless battery life after a year anyway, it's not really any loss by comparison.

UPDATE: Now on number 6.  Number 4 was lost never to be seen again.  Number 5 had was defective. Recommend staying away from the 'bulk' packaged Jawbone prime.  I've had two instances where the audio clarity is terrible when I've gotten one of the bulk Jawbones (just means no OEM box, the bluetooth comes packaged in bags but still includes all accessories).  Could be coincidence, but definitely make sure if you are ordering from a third party vendor and not Amazon directly that they have a good return policy.
summary: Good for the hard to fit ear

reviewText:
Killer product! After watching multiple videos on these products, and having had a number of cup holder, vent based, and CD slot type phone holders I settled on this dashboard mount.  Installation was simple--pulling off the cover on the bottom adhesive pad, positioning it on the dashboard, push down and actuate the rear vacuum switch.  (There is also another pad in the package if you have some odd shaped surface).  After the first day, I decided to reposition it.  With some minor pulling, the entire unit came loose, leaving a clean dashboard and the same adhesive surface ready for repositioning.  Amazing?!

Sitting on the dashboard, both portrait and landscape viewing is possible with an easily articulated head.  The head moves in all directions (restricted only by the dashboard and the base itself).  The movement of the head is tight enough to hold position during driving and general use, but not so tight as to make it difficult to move when necessary.  Surprisingly, on an iPhone 6, I can position the bottom side edges of the phone in order to actually use the phone as a camera or take videos while driving--it is no mounted "Go-Pro" but it works for me.

A couple of reviewers (notably ZacK Hill with videos) provided all the information I needed to make the right purchase, especially by showing the actual installation and then showing how stable a given installation might be. THANKS for the helpful reviews.  I am happy with this purchase and will buy another for a second vehicle.

reviewText: Perfect!

I never got a case for my phone because they are usually bulky and feel weird to touch, but after 2 screen cracks I decided it's time to get a case. I'm so glad I went with this one

PROS:
* Feel: The case feels amazing in my hands. It's got a nice grip and a sharp, solid feel
* Protection: The edges raise above the screen and the corners are padded, so your phone's protected. I dropped my phone flat on its face and it was fine when I picked it up. This thing's payed for itself already
* Look: The case has an iron-man-esque look to it, and the colors complement the iPhone's design
* Slim: The case doesn't add much dimension to the phone, so it's not bulky
* Vibration: The case doesn't interfere with the phone's vibration, so you can leave it on mute and still feel calls

CONS:
* Buttons: The buttons require a lot more force to press, and the mute switch is harder to access
* Dust: The edges of cutouts for the bottom (headphone,mic,charge,speaker) will build up dust because the dust has no way out. Easily remedied by a once-a-week/month cleaning, depending on how much you care about it

reviewText: Works great! No complaints.

Where to start...ordered this case for 8 dollars and change with an Amazon coupon after reading some reviews that were not favorable. In the meantime I had been shopping around to no avail and even went to Wal-Mart and tried to find an Otter box for the Note 5, sorry they don't carry them, period.  But out of curiosity, I checked out the ones for the 8 just to see the quality.

Anyway, my case arrived and it is perfect. I see NO difference in quality from the Otter box series at silly prices for what you get, especially at Wal-Mart no less, and as I said, they only carry cases for the 9, 8, and down to 7 on the S series so save the trip.
In fact, I think this design is better.
I like it WAY better.

First off... it's easy to grip because it has the cut out pattern on the sides of the inner shell. The phone control buttons are still snapy and work well. Everything lines up well plenty of room to plug in head phones, cord, and S Pen clicks out easily. The cut outs are large in other words. Case fits tight and snug on my Note 5. Reviews that say theirs does not fit got the wrong case my guess. I mean there is no way this can't fit snug.

It has a hard rubbery feel. Does not add much bulk to the very slippery glass backed phone. Even with inner and outer shells on.
It looks much bulkier in the picture. My last case on my Note 4 was all flat and rubbery. It did not really slide, even on a dashboard. This will. It is not that gell like sticky rubber.

So, I really like the outer shell option with the stand. This is the design you see with the pattern of raised little squares. Inside shell is flat and smooth. Outer has the same feel as inner shell, like a hard, yet plyable rubbery plastc. It was similar to the Otterbox feel.

Outerbshell snaps on easily at the four corners and two trips in the middle to the inner shell.  Once on, that outer shell is not going anywhere, fits nice and snug.

Stand is nice, works well, easy to deploy and snaps securely into place.  It is on a When done, it easily closes and snaps securely flat. Like anything, if you are rough with the stand, impatient, it will break, no matter what brand.  If you are gentle, you will get some good use. Stand does have a metal hinge pin, and a metal snap in pin, similar to a bigger watch pin. It's not just plastic with a crease or those horrible magnetic deals that RUIN your phone...no. Stand fold down pretty close to flat with pattern. This should easily fit in your vehicle holders. Things are smooth feeling, corners nicesly rounded, should not snag in pockets.

Even if the stand breaks in time, I would still buy another one because no where have I seen the kind of secure grip this offers. All your five fingers fit nicely right in the groves of the cut out pattern. Great when typing or taking pictures or videos. Hard to explain.
This would be great for people with small or even large hands, maybe a clumsy grip, surely for anyone that has dexterity problems.

You can wireless charge with the case on as well.

Getting another to put away...incase they discontinue for sure.

Hope this helps....
summary: Very Good Case. Very good looking, NOT cheesy or cheap. N

reviewText: My first Anker external battery was the Astro Mini, which still goes practically everywhere with me. It's small and lightweight and has just enough juice to get me by if I'm caught with a dying phone battery and no place to plug in. And that seems to happen more than it should (my phone seems to be able to get to about 5:00 and call that the end of its work day). I like my Astro Mini a lot but the round shape is a bit awkward to carry in a front pocket. And of course it wants to roll off a desk or table all the time. So much to my joy, Anker has introduced their latest battery which addresses a need at the exact opposite end of their trend to make bigger and even bigger batteries. The E1. It's kind of like a squooshed Astro Mini ... about the same length (3.8" vs 3.7") and still only 0.9" high. The width is a bit more at 1.7" vs 0.9" and the weight is 4.2oz vs 3.0oz. Yet, because of the very rounded case it actually feels about the same size and actually feels slightly lighter. It DEFINITELY fits more comfortably into the front pocket of my jeans. The E1, at $24.99 packs a significantly bigger punch than the $19.99 Astro Mini - 5200mAh vs 3200mAh and that is the #1 most exciting improvement. Now instead of a quick boost to let me make a few more phone calls or send a few emails, the E1 can get me through the entire evening with enough reserve power to give my iPad Mini a boost. More power isn't the only improvement though. The E1 has Anker's ubiquitous mini LED status lights so I know exactly how much power I have left. It also features Anker's PowerIQ amp-adjustment technology which intelligently identifies your device to deliver its fastest possible charge. The design of the E1 complements the rest of the E1 series of external batteries (however with only one USB charging port and no flashlight). The only (and insignificant) difference is the exclusion of the mesh carrying bag which, frankly, I would never use for a battery of this size. Anker has scored another home run with the E1 and sorry to say I've reserved a place in my front pocket to replace my Astro Mini (which now lives in my car's storage compartment). It would be hard not to rate this as a true 5-star product.
summary: Perfect pocket size - packs a punch

reviewText: Got to me ripped. Dont buy

I have always come to depend on UAG for their extremely simple, yet rugged cases and their clear-case for the Samsung S6 Edge is just another example of UAG living up to their reputation.

The case fits on very tightly, as one would expect, and the acrylic materials provide excellent flexibility to get the device in but still exert excellent protection.  The clear coating with black trimming looks really good with the white S6 so I wouldn't recommend it for the black sapphire.

Also, unlike most cases, the UAG does not interfere with the buttons so, while it may seem stiff at first, one can still operate the buttons with ease and not worry about any "runoff" and, by that, I mean having your fingers accidentally hit other buttons while touching the home button.  One of my biggest gripes on open-faced cases is that the case overlaps onto the screen too much so when you hit the home button you repeatedly hit another button cause you have to hover half your thumb over the case.

All in all, the UAG is an excellent case and the clear is perfect for the white S6.
summary: As Rugged As One Would Expect From UAG

reviewText:
Hi Everyone today we will be reviewing the Bike Phone Mount Kit package.

Purpose:
I'm avid mountain biker, Bicycling is my passion and due to  hectic family and professional life i sometimes end up going for bicycling when the sun goes down or just when it gets dark early in winter time. The number 1 priority for me is to be visible, do everything one can do to make sure that others motorists see you and that you can also see well in the dark. I also like to listen to songs while i cycle and i hate to keep the phone in my pocket. Enter Bike phone mount kit.

Product Description (First Impression)
It comes in a nice packaging box, 4 items in the box, 1 bike mount which holds the phone, 2 secure flex bands, front bike light and its mount, rear tail light. In general everything is made of plastic with few rubber mounts to hold the phone and screws to tighten the clamps.  The flashlight has the capability of zooming the light X1 to X2000. The torch and the tail light have different patterns for example on 1 click they will switch on, on second click they will flicker and on 3rd will blink. No Manual, comes with 3 AAA batteries.

Pros:
1: The head lights is probably the best part, excellent quality! the torch has a zooming functionality and you can literally focus the torch to a small square or zoom out to cover a larger area.
2: The torch comes with 3 AAA batteries , so you don't have to buy some.
3: The clamps that tighten the phone screw into a metal nut , this guarantee's that the clamps and the tightening can be efficiently re used.
4: I like that the clamps has rubber padding inside the clamps this was my bicycle bar will not get scratched.
5: The one clamp which holds the phone i really liked because now i don't have to keep my phone in my pocket , this way the phone stays safe and i can listen to songs over my wireless blue tooth headphones.

Cons:
1:The plastic that is used to make all these parts i felt sometimes was not the best of the quality, like the cylinder that holds the bike lights doesn't feel sturdy and strong enough but its not to the point that its of any concern.
2: Remember to tighten the screws which hold the phone before you put it on the bicycle or it is difficult the tighten it from under the bar.
3: I tightened the clamp that holds the torch but when i was to press the button which switches on the torch it was sliding out of is holding clamp. this is not a show stopper but need to hold the torch before you press the button to switch it on.
4: Does not come with an instruction manual.

Verdict:
All in all this is an excellent product for people who like to go cycling when there is a chance that there might not be enough light or it might be dark,
The tail light is bright and functions in 3 modes which is nice. I would highly recommend this product, it is a must have for cyclists.

Please review the attached pictures and feel free to leave comments or ask questions and i will be more than happy to answer them.

NOTE: I received this product at a discount for my honest review and trust me if i had bought it at full price my review would still be exactly the same.

Regards,
Nick Hill
A bad review is like baking the perfect cake with all the best ingredients and having someone sit on it!
summary: IN DEPTH REVIEW - Bike Phone Mount Kit

Over the past year I've got to try many different powerbanks with low capacity (2600 mAh) and high capacity (20000mAh) out of all 10,000 mAh powerbanks I own I think this one is by far the best one out all other which doesn't have the solar panel that charges it as soon as the sunlight hits it. This durable solar panel is what makes this powerbank top all of the other powerbanks I own, the size is not huge like some bulkie ones or too heavy which makes it almost unnoticeable in My back pocket, it's about the thickness of 2 phones (I tested it with 2 oneplus two phones) and a bit wider and longer then the phones. I really like fact there is a place to snap a hook on it and carry it around you while it's going to keep charging as long as there is sunlight making sure you always have battery.
The plastic is super smooth and the hole thing feels very durable, the USB ports have a small led flashlight which isn't the brightest light though it will help you find the key hole to your door when it's dark outside. Charging time from empty to full on a charger took me about 6-7 hours, I didn't spend 6-7 hours outside yet but I'm pretty sure it will take a bit more then that with the solar panel, I did get about 30 minutes of sun that charged my phone though it did not have enough time to get it from 1 to 2 bars.
Overall this Powerbank is made out of durable materials, looks great, Works like a champ and easy to carry around.
I'm thankful I was able to receive this product at a discounted price in exchange for my unbiased opinion and honest review
Seller and Amazon were great and shipping was extremely fast of course.
Thank you for a superb service and product.
summary: Loving it, solar panel works great, very durable, good quality, lightweight, easy to carry around.

reviewText: Great buy, excellect qulaity. Feels sturdy and well made, all buttons are covered with rubber, doesn't squeak while driving. Definitely would recommend it.

It fits the HTC One M8 like a glove. It clearly exposes the top and the bottom for better function ability. The volume control is also easy to use. The cut outs for the camera work well and no shadowing occurred in any of my photos I took. As i stated the top and bottom are fully exposed so those two areas are vunerable but it is important to keep the top open for connectivity and the buttom exposed for connecting to powering devices, stereos, and head phones, etc... The shell is hard with a rubber outer layer to cradle your phone and for a non slip feel. I have had quite a lot of smart phones and found less is more and to take care of my investment. Unless your in a work environment that demands a case that fully covers and has several layers of protective rubber and plastic all you really need is a $6.00 case and maybe a screen protector. I was looking around my office the other day and i noticed that some of our computers cost less than our phones and they never get dented or scratches that would lead us to buy protective wear for them instead we treat them in a correct manner. So we apply that same philosophy to our phones we invest thousands on. Don't stick your phone in your back pocket that is where your wallet goes and if you were not aware you sit on you bottom and that is where your back pocket is. If your phone is there it is going to get sat on. I bought really nice clutches for the ladies in our company to place their phones in and the guys got a screen protector and a simple case like this. A year later 22 out of 22 were returned as they were given and the leather clutches and simple cases were far less than any extreme protective case and accessories. I say again if you are in the line of work where you need a multilayered protective case than this case is not for you. If you are a parent with toddlers then this case may not be for you. But if you are a responsibile adult that knows how to properly take care of your investment in a smartphone this is perfect. No need to spend $80.00 on a case then another $15.00 on adapters so you can hook it up to a computer or sound system or anything for that matter. This case is just fine. I learned a long time ago less is best. Isn't that what these devices are made for to simplify our lives? Personally i don't use a case and all my phone are and have been well taken care of which has been a great return in investment due to reselling them after they are unlocked and I upgrade to the next latest and greatest. Think about it you wear an expensive watch and you try your best to take care of it and due to that it may last you years. The same applies to jewelry you take care of it and it shines just like the day you bought it and you don't go buy a $80.00 case to cover its beauty.
summary: Great Bare Bones Case for the HTC One M8

I recently got a Samsung Epic 4g, and decided that a phone cover would be a good investment (no brainer, I know...).

Anyway, since I'm new to the world of smart phones I decided to try a few different kinds of covers and see how I liked them.  One of my test run options was the Otterbox Commuter.

Likes:
- Good reputation - we've owned and been happy with other Otterbox products at our home
- Solid construction
- Rubber inner liner and button protection
- Hard plastic outer cover
- Rubber covers/protection for charging port, earphone jack port, etc.

Dislikes:
- The cover made the phone feel a bit too bulky for my taste.
- Outer plastic cover felt more slippery in my hand than my phone by itself - I kept thinking it was going to slip out of my hand.
- Didn't care for the way the power on/off button seemed to be up under the edge of the plastic outer cover, and was not as easily accessible as I'd like.  It wasn't too bad it you reached around behind the phone to access the button, but it wasn't as easily accessed if you reached for the power button from the front side.

Final decision - returned the unit and continued my search for a better match for my personal preferences.

I do not doubt that this cover would protect my phone.  There were just a few things, more personal than anything, that led me to keep looking.

4 stars - but not 5 IMO
summary: No sale after a test run - there were a few things I didn't want to have to get used to.

reviewText: The VTIN Bluetooth Stereo Sports Headphones offer a lot of features in a very compact set. The set is designed with to fit in the ears and the cable loops behind the neck. There is a buckle that comes with the set to allow you to adjust the length of the cable. The cable is a flat cable, so this prevents it from coiling or twisting up. There is a hard cover case which will hold the entire headset plus the accessories. There is a hook that can be used to attach the case to your backpack or other gear for ease of transportation. In addition to the carrying case and aluminum hook, the set comes with 3 sets of ear hooks and three sets of ear buds in various sizes. The ear pieces fit inside the ear. The headphones operates on a lithium ion battery that will provide about 7 hours of play/talk time. The controls are all on the right ear piece. The large circular button in the middle is the on/off and a multi-function switch. The volume up/down is on the side. The unit has a built in mic that works very well. The sound quality both for music and for phone conversations is excellent. This is a very good headset and is priced very competitively. I was provided a sample for testing/review purposes.
Very good case with nice bright colors!
Pretty, very girly, fits perfect, and great protection. We gave our 3 1/2 year old an old phone to play with and she's in love with her new phone case.

Before we begin to talk about the product, let's talk a minute about the box it was shipped in. It's nothing fancy at first; it's not in crazy plastic. It was not hard to open the box at all, no scissors were required! And the included instructions and "Happy?" or "Not Happy?" pamphlet shows the company cares about you as their customer and wants to make sure you are completely satisfied! I have just never seen something quite like this in any product I've bought in the past. I also like how simple the instructions were, quite brief, direct, and to the point, showing how to check the battery life, how to charge your device, and how to charge the battery. There is a QR code inside that will quickly direct you to more information about your product. Also, the instructions state a 30-day money back guarantee, 18-month hassle free warranty, and lifetime user support. This company is straight up astounding!

The battery itself is really slick looking and feels great in the hands, has some nice weight to it. The battery life indicator button has a good click to it and responds quickly to show your battery life. Only one side has your charging ports, one for charging the battery (clearly labeled as INPUT and takes a micro USB cable which is included with the product), and another for your device you are charging. Here's the good thing: this battery works with your iDevice as well as Android, and I have also tried a few other devices around the house like a bluetooth speaker, and it has worked fine. As far as charging, it charges pretty fast!

If you have a wife or girlfriend, watch out, because when mine saw this laying on the table, she said, "Oh cool! My phone is about to die, can I take this and use it?" I encouraged her to, and she really enjoyed how convenient it was to bring in her purse and charge her iPhone. This really opened up the possibilities of where to take it and when to use it. My father in law has one like this that he uses for hiking. When our car's charger is being used for the GPS, I can use the battery for charging up my phone.

This product is perfect compared to a lot of the ones on the market that, to me, just look cheap. They don't charge quickly, they don't work with all of my devices, and they don't always charge, plus the company I bought them from never really cared to know what I thought of their product. Anker, however, does care about you, and the quality behind this product shows they have been listening to their market.

I got this product for free through their Power User program, and I was not paid to write this review. The product has really served its purpose over the past couple weeks and I do recommend it.

The biggest gripe with this product is its non natural feel. It has a sticky/rubbery feel to it that just feels off.

I have to admit, this is my first "wet" screen protector. I have absolutely no issues applying it. After a few hours, the bubbles were all gone. The protector fits perfectly (too perfect). While this would be a great aspect for other phones, for the Nexus 4, this can be seen as a negative attribute since the screen is slightly curved at the edges.

With the screen protector so close to the edge (that curves), it leaves a greater possibility that the screen may lift up and create bubbles on the edges. Well, this happened to mine after 2 weeks of normal use. I do NOT use a case. I keep it in my front pocket all day.

I can live with the small bubbles on the edges, but I just can't seem to get used to the rubbery feel of the screen.

OK, so I'm sure you may be wondering if this case/holster combo is worth the price, and at $50 that's a good question...to which I must proudly proclaim yes! Don't forget you're covering a phone that retails at $599, so the price here is really quite small.  Also, you could get an OtterBox case for the same price, but honestly, those things are over-rated, bulky, boxy...This product is not.  now, they call this a Convert, based on the fact that you COULD take off the silicon shell and plastic skeleton and just use the soft-touch plastic shell for your phone, but  you and I both know you're looking at this case because you want more than that.  Let me tell you, Seidio doesn't disappoint. As usual, this offers superior quality, and comfortability in design.  The case does add some bulk to the phone, but if you ask me, it's not too much.  it still keeps a sleek design, rounded off comfortably, and soft to the touch.  Your volume and power keys are covered, and with this model even your power port and headphone jack are covered by nicely fit flaps that seem to basically be sealed when closed.  If you're like me, you probably use YouTube, Netflix, or Google Movies on your phone, so you'll love the sturdy metal kickstand which is spring loaded for easy access.

One thing about this gigantic phone is that it doesn't sit comfortably in your pocket, and this holster is perfect for this.  holster is sturdy, locks the holding clip if you don't want the device to accidentally be removed...the only drawback for me is that the holster does not cover the screen entirely, but that's really not a deal breaker in my book.

Also, one nice little surprise I got is that Seidio included one of their screen protectors free with this product!

anyway, I'm a big fan of Seidio products, and have used their Active case on several devices, but I wanted to step it up and get the Convert this time, which I am extremely glad I did.  Buy it, you will not be disappointed!

This screen protector is crystal clear and I'm not exaggerating. There are no rainbow colors that are seen unlike some other screen protectors. There seem to be more finger print smudges on the screen than without the protector, but it's not a big deal since it's very easy to wipe them off.

I took one star off because of the feel. It doesn't have the smooth feel to it as you do without the screen protector, but you get used to it after a few days.

Overall - I would definitely recommend that you buy this product. I really like it.

This is the most impressive screen protector I've used, both in regards to screen clarity and protection. The surfaces come sealed in an airtight, pouch that was easy to tear open, maintaining dust-free protectors from factory to application.

The application of the surfaces is about as easy as it gets for this type of product; cut to the perfect shape, these look great once they are on. The instructions suggest using the squeegee after the surface application to remove bubbles; I suggest using it during application. So long as there are no particles of dust on either the phone or the protective surface, the results are very nice.

I am sure these protectors will keep the glass from breaking under many circumstances, but curiosity does not tempt me to prove anything beyond what Lifeworks has done in their product demonstration video.

Although these protect the glass surfaces of my iPhone, the edges of the phone are as exposed as ever, which I knew they would be, I just wanted to test the product. I have dropped my phones before, and impact is usually at corners, so I do prefer a full-body protective case.

If I want to keep my phone compact, I will use Commando; the clear surfaces have lasting durability. The combination of layers gives this product an advantage over "competing" multipacks of typical screen protectors, which scuff so easily and are in need of replacement after a short time.

We've had lots of different charging cables over the years, but always in white or black colors.  I was attracted to the thirty three colors ZeroLemon offers to choose from in this cable.  My daughter is crazy about pink, so I asked for that one.

We tested out this cable on my daughter's iphone 5, and found that it charged as fast as the one that came with the phone.  We didn't feel any heat in the cable, and felt that the connecting pins were well made and secure.  It comes with a 2-year warranty, which is more than most vendors give for their cables.

We also really liked that this cable is 10 feet long.  This allows her to use her phone while it's charging, and allows her to put the phone on her nightstand as an alarm clock while it's plugged into her laptop.  Overall we're really pleased with this cable, and I give it 5 stars for both the performance and the color selection.  Why have a boring, basic black cord when you can one that matches your phone case or personality?

I received a complimentary ZeroLemon Lightning to USB cable for testing and review purposes.  I wasn't pressured to leave a good review, and this is my honest opinion of the product.
summary: Apple-Approved, reliable, well made and comes in great colors

Once charged (see note!), the phone works very nicely.
Using the android setup app that opened automatically on startup, I easily added my account and contact info, setup the security features and made my first phone calls.
The physical appointments of this phone are nice - it has a big (5 inch) attractive, colorful and easy to read screen. Netflix movies look great!
A metal strip surrounds the screen, adding a nice touch of elegance. The plastic back has a leatherette texture which feels nice in the hand.
Internet connectivity is good.  At home, the Dash found both of my wifi networks and easily connected. Once online, my browsing experience is smooth and effortless.  The powerful processor in this device is really evident when browsing, streaming video or listening to music. No buffering or interruptions.
With bluetooth on I easily found and connected to several different headsets.
Phone calls are efficient and clear, although I wish I could boost the volume a bit higher. Its a bit quiet.
The sim card I used is a T-Mobile that I've had for about ten years - and the phone had no problem setting it up.
I'm new to the Android OS, but found it easy to use and efficient.
Note: This was not a difficult setup, but it was not a quick start either, as the battery was not anywhere close to being charged when it arrived. You need to fully charge before using this phone. Plugging in is simple - and there are indicator lights on the phone - a red one while charging that changes to green when charging is finished.
Be patient: Using the included charger, mine took over 4 hours, after some false starts (there were a few warnings from the phone that my "battery is too cold - please unplug from the charger". For my second charge-up, I used the charger from my Lumia Windows phone - it charged the phone much more quickly. I've been topping up with a dc charger in my car and it works fine.
Although this phone multitasks very nicely, be aware that the battery life is much better when you remember to turn off apps when you are done! I've noticed that apps open on shutdown reopen at startup! The Dash M. has a "recent apps" button right on the home screen, so its not hard to turn off apps when you're done. If you have a lot open there is a "clear all" option to close them all at once, a good idea when you are shutting down.
Overall, I'm impressed with this phone. It is simple to use, has a deep feature set, a clear screen and good, if quiet sound.
summary: Simple to use, deep feature set, big screen!

+ Good volume

- When you push the on off button, your finger covers the light which tells you when it turns on or off
- Very hard to get it to sit against your cheek all the time (as it needs to in order to function properly)

I am comparing this tp the Jabra BT8040 I have been using for the last year, which was great, but not loud enough in the car with my 8330 Pearl Blackberry. I got the Jawbone 2 for the added volume.  The Jawbone seemed to be the "ipod of earpieces", so I figured I could not go wrong.  It works ok, but the lack of real buttons makes it difficult to use, and it feels delicate.  Also, it has to sit against your cheek all the time to make it work, but it doesn't like to stay there, as you move your head around, it moves off.  However I have to say I never had a problem hearing or being heard, so that is great.  I miss the A2DP, which allows you to play music from your phone to the earpiece.  Overall good, but unless I am in a noisy environment, I will stick with my Jabra, which is tiny, durable, and has the A2DP, the Jawbone will stay in the car.

The Sony Xperia X Performance is a great choice if you want a powerful, full-featured but don't want to carry around a huge tablet-sized smartphone.

Ive used this phone in lieu of my trusted iPhone 6s for about 5 days and will try to provide some 1:1 comparisons:

Phone Size, Screen and Case Material: The Xperia is much more compact compared to most Android tablets on the market, yet the screen is still very crisp and bright.  I don't feel a major loss in resolution compared to a larger sized screen. The metal finish is attractive but I am still partial to the seamless look and feel of the Apple devices personally. That being said, the phone does feel very solid and high quality in its construction. The finish and glass screen seem durable, yet the curved glass may make it difficult for a screen protect to stay put.

Performance: The Snapdragon 820 is a highly rated processor and seems to run this phone quite nicely.  I am less partial to the Sony launcher and apps compared to Samsung and HTC, but thats a personal preference. The posted 3GB of RAM seem to be adequate and the battery life is also very excellent and on par with my iPhone 6S.

Audio: Unlike iOS based iPhones, you gain a lot of flexibility with the Xperia in both apps and expandability.  The micro SD slot can accommodate another 200gb of storage.  Alongside the music player, which can accommodate lossless audio files (i.e. FLAC), you have a really amazing MP3 player.

Camera and Display: The heart and soul of this camera is Sonys amazing 23MP rear and 18MP front cameras.  As expected (being a Sony camera enthusiast), they provide amazing photos in a variety of settings and are certainly a huge selling point for this particular model.

A few features I didn't like:
Full app/notification customization (you won't be able to turn off OS integrated ads easily)
Lack of Fingerprint scanner
summary: Small but powerful with excellent features

reviewText: The actual cover seems to be of high quality, and will certainly keep the phone's screen scratchless.  However, after I installed the product according to the instructions, (perfect alignment first try!) the top left and top right edges of the protector do not seal against the phone's screen. This is likely due to the curved profile of the screen, but will likely lead to dust and lint collecting under the protector, and eventually the unsealed section will spread out to the point that the protector will need to be replaced.  As this is a 2-pack, when the first protector wears out, I will attempt to place the second protector slightly further down (very slightly, as the home button is currently only about 1.6mm away from the protector.) in hopes that it will properly seal.  If this works, I will update my review accordingly.
summary: Good protection, but the curved screen makes it tricky to form a 100% seal.

reviewText: OK

This is a good quality screen protector, but has one major flaw that led me to remove it.  I am aware that it is difficult if not impossible to make a curved glass screen protector.  I knew this going in.  The major flaw I saw was that it is far too narrow and short and could cover more of the screen and NOT be in danger of ending up on the curved sides.  There is more than 1mm of space on the left and right sides if the screen protector is centered.  Further, there is several millimeters of space between the top and bottom of the screen if the protector is centered.  This caused dust/debris to accumulate at the edges of the screen protector at a pretty rapid pace and increased maintenance.

The perfect glass screen protector would take you to within .5mm of the screen edges on the sides and be a near perfect fit vertically.  I recently picked up a Spigen screen protector (not glass, unfortunately) that does exactly this--it covers everything except the curve itself.  I also use the Spigen Rugged Armor case with that screen Spigen protector and everything is good now.
summary: Not bad, but far from good

reviewText:
Full disclosure, I purchased the i9200 from an eBay seller as there are no 16gb versions available for this device on amazon. Price was four seventy nine for the 16gb version.  I found the 8gb version of this phone severely limited the amount of apps I could download. 16gb is perfect as I could download multiple 3D HD games like dead trigger, need for speed and ashphalt hd without filling up the phones internal storage.  I also purchased the i9205 LTE version from Amazon about a month ago but I had to return that device since it had some issues.

I'm a Galaxy Note user who has had the note since September of 2011. When the Note 2 came out I decided to skip it because I didn't think it was that worthy of an upgrade. So the Note has been my primary device for almost 2 years.

Like you, I discovered the Mega 6.3 and began reading up on it and watching video reviews online. My initial worry was that it wouldn't be as fast as the current flagships and that I'd regret buying a device with last years specs.

My reasoning to go ahead an purchase the Mega was based on the fact that to me it would feel like an upgrade since I was coming from my old Note.

After using the Mega all my fears of it being underpowered and slow were gone. The device has a large bright crisp LCD display which I can now see clearly in daylight! The 1.5 GB RAM is handling my multitasking very well as I've yet seen a launcher redraw occur. The device is very snappy and has had no issues playing large MKV files. One of the coolest features that I was excited about was the IR port. Now you can control all your living room devices with your phone. The i9200 camera is on par with the galaxy note 2. For some reason the mega 6.3 i9205 that I tested had a poor performing camera. This i9200 performs much better,  not sure if different firmware is the reason. Either way I'm much happier with the camera quality on the i9200.

The big win with this phone is the sheer amount of real estate you get. The original Note fits within the Mega 6.3's display area. You aren't just getting a phone when you get a Mega 6.3 you are also getting a small tablet. This device is a true Phablet. While the Note 1 and 2 were big devices the Mega elevates the browsing and media viewing experience to a true tablet level experience. If this is what you are interested in then I highly recommend picking up this device. So to recap, this device has a great display, versatile form factor, decent camera and great performance.

And I hope I don't understate that the battery life is AMAZING!. I'm used to phones beeping low battery warnings around 5-6pm. With the Mega I no longer have to worry about my battery life. I literally cannot kill the battery. By the time I hook up the charger at night its 11PM and the Mega still has 20% battery left. And this is with HEAVY usage. I can take the Mega off charger at 6am and still have battery left in the very late evening.

If you are trying to win the antutu, quadrant benchmark wars then I suggest you stay away from the Mega as the S4 is the current flagship which is putting up crazy benchmark numbers.

If you are looking for a large crisp HD display with last years flagship specs and excellent real world performance then the Mega 6.3 is your device. The only thing that should hold you back from this purchase is whether you want to wait for the Note 3 which will have the S-Pen, better camera and a 1080P display. The Mega 6.3 I picked up was the 16gb version for four seventy nine shipped from e bay. The unlocked international note 3 will start at mid $700's most likely.

I can personally confirm that this phone (i9200) does work on AT&T 3G and 2G frequencies. My Mega 6.3 i9200 is running on AT&T 3G HSPA+. Unlike the unlocked Note N7000 and Galaxy S II I didn't have to enter any APN settings when I inserted my AT&T SIM. The Mega automatically defined the proper AT&T APN settings and the 3G was working great. You will need a MICRO SIM for this phone. If you have a standard sized SIM you can either cut it down to MICRO SIM size or visit an AT&T store and ask for a MICRO SIM.

The Mega 6.3 GT i9200 will NOT work with ANY AMERICAN LTE (4G) frequency. In North America we use LTE frequencies 700, 800, 1900, 1700, 2100 MHz which are bands 4, 12, 13, 17, 25

AT&T uses BAND 4 and 17 Frequencies 1700/2100 for Band 4 and 700 for Band 17

T-Mobile uses BAND 4 Frequencies 1700/2100 AWS

The i9200 has NO LTE radio so AT&T 3G HSPA+ is all you will get with the GT i9200 here in the United States. You will get 2G on T-Mobile or 3.5G HSPA if you are in an area where T-mobile has refarmed their 1900 band. This phone isn't compatible with Verizon.

******************************************************************************************************ATT subscribers may ask themselves why should they buy the full price unlocked phone versus the $99 on contract Mega 6.3 that AT&T is currently offering? Well one major reason is that the AT&T Mega 6.3 has a locked boot loader. If you don't know what that means then you should get your Mega 6.3 directly from AT&T. However if you enjoy performing modifications to your phone such as rooting and flashing custom roms then the i9200 and i9205 are the only options you have with the Mega 6.3. You currently cannot root the AT&T Mega 6.3, please be aware of this if you are thinking about purchasing directly from AT&T and are hoping to root the AT&T Mega 6.3
*****************************************************************************************************

If you purchase this unlocked international device from Amazon or any other online retailer and you live in the United States, Samsung will not warranty your phone. Buying an unlocked grey market phone that was not specifically released for your country (USA) is not eligible under Samsung's 1 year warranty. Please consider this before you purchase any unlocked international Samsung phones as they will not be covered under the Samsung warranty (It doesn't matter what the Amazon seller puts in the description about this). If you want a warranty from Samsung then either wait for your carrier (T-Mobile, AT&T etc.) to carry the phone or purchase a 3rd party warranty from a vendor like Square Trade. You've been warned.

reviewText: works great,

I have the droid turbo in ballistic nylon and I have wanted some protection but didn't want to cover up the cool looking nylon side. So I've purchased 3-4 case that were clear on the back. Now some things to look out for is if the buttons work, if the case has a lip for the front, if the case is slick or rubbery (easy to hold onto), and most important if it's easy to see through (some have had a matte finish and you couldn't really see through others get scratched easily so you can't see through them after you use them a bit.

This case so far is the best of the bunch. All buttons work perfectly (volume even better than without a case) The grip is excellent. I dropped my phone really hard one time and it just made a quiet bouncy noise as it landed on the side. I also protect the front with tempered glass and together with this case I feel my phone is pretty secure. It's not an otter box mind you but then again I don't need a suitcase to carry my phone. I'm astonished at how resistant it is to scratching and I got the smokey color but it's still easy to see the blue nylon through it. Plenty of room for the camera lens, charger and headphones. definitely a 5 star case at a great price on amazon.
summary: This is the best clear case I've got for my ballistic turbo yet

reviewText: It was a cute design. But it didn't fit (I have S4). Fast shipping but I guess you get what you pay for. Would not recommend this.

The GOOD: Once you have  trained and conditioned the phone and battery. This battery works well as far as providing power for long periods of time without having to charge the phone so often.

The not so BAD: The case does not have any type of kick stand. I had to fashion one myself.

The Bad: If you have to remove the battery. You have to be very careful. Pull the battery away from the top where connectors are. The connectors on the battery are recessed. The battery casing catches on the phones connectors and pulls them from the phone. This damages the phone's charging ability.

The WORST: The battery swells. This is common with some Lithium Ion batteries. This battery is so swollen that it bulged and split its casing. The bulging battery pushes against the case. The case is so tight now that it is pulling the phone and causing the phone to bend and separate the screen from the phone casing. I now have to send my phone in for repair or buy a replacement.

In the middle of winter my sister-in-law was going shopping. She had gotten everything she needed and went up to the checkout, stood in line, loaded everything onto the belt and waited for the cashier to ring her up. Now my sister-in-law and I both will sometimes leave our purses in the car and just take our phones and wallets with us if we're planning to be in the store for quite a while and don't feel like lugging a purse around. That's exactly what she did that day. So when the cashier told her the total my sister-in-law opened up her wallet to get her debit card. It wasn't in there! She had forgotten earlier that she had dropped in into a pocket in her purse. Which was in the car. On the other side of the mall. I think you can image the rest and her embarrassment.

Needless to say I came across this iPhone wallet case and knew I needed to get it for her! It's perfect and she loves it, she's always got it with her now and is never without her cards, ID or phone. The strap on it is really handy to carry the case, she just wraps it around her wrist. It can hold up to 9 cards I think and one of the spots has a little window for her driver's license to show through. There's also no worry that the cards will scratch up the iPhone because the flap they are on closes and the side that actually touches the phone is flat with nothing on it. reviewText:
I have an iPhone 5s and need a case to protect it very well.  I have used the Otterbox Defender Series case for my iPhone 5s.  While it protects my phone, it is very bulky.  I have a number of New Trent products and have always regarded them as high quality and innovative.  So, I wanted to get the New Trent Ultra-Thin iPhone 5/5S case.  I wanted a different alternative to find something both rugged and very thin.

I was impressed by the product when I received it.  It is much thinner than my Otterbox.  It is highly protective with 3 pieces, an outer soft TPU case, hard inner case and a polycarbonate interchangeable back cover.
The screen protector is integrated into the hard case and is scratch resistant and extremely clear.  It is very responsive to my touch.  I have used other cases that were not responsive.

One unique feature is that it has a thin protector for the fingerprint home button.  The Otterbox does not have that.  It provides extra protection, yet is still sensitive.

Another unique feature is a film over the microphone.  Again, other cases do not have that feature.  The film does not interfere with the microphone at all.  I like that protection.

Finally, another unique feature is a protective film over the camera and flash.  I have taken pictures with and without the flash in the case.  The pictures are not affected by the film.  I like that protection.

This case provides water resistance, which is important for a protective case.  I especially want it for the iPhone 5s.  My Otterbox Defender is not water resistant.  When I go out in the rain, I worry about that. Also, when I take my iPhone 5s on a boat, I need that water resistance around any splashing.

I have used this New Trent case and it seems to be durable.  The screen protector may get fingerprints on it over time, especially if your fingers are dirty or greasy, but that has occurred with every case that I have every owned.  It is no problem.  All you do is wipe it occasionally with a cloth and it is fine.  It seems to be more fingerprint resistant that many cases that I have owned.

This case is very thin and rugged.  Because of the water resistance and extra protection, as well as the thin form factor, I would rate this case as a 5 out of 5, with 5 being excellent and 1 being bad.
The only negative is that there is no belt clip.  I do like the option of a clip to carry it on my belt, although I often just put it in a pocket.

I find that this product is especially suitable and helpful when I travel.  I need a protective and rugged case.  The occupations that would benefit the most from this case are people who travel, like sales people and consultants.  It would also be best for people around construction sites, like architects or contractors or people in the trades.  It would be good for real estate agents who have to go to different properties.  Although, I am a corporate finance professional, I find it useful for my travels as well as just going around town.  It is one of the best cases that I have discovered and I recommend this for anyone who wants to protect their iPhone.
summary: One of the best cases for an iPhone 5S

It didn't affect the item at all, but first impressions are very important. I think they could have used more tape when packaging the item to avoid a very little, minor, and petty incident like this. reviewText:
I really truly wanted to like this product because I am a big proponent of virtual reality and Google Cardboard for mobile devices but my one complaint about Google Cardboard is that there just isn't any good way of controlling the games aside from tilting your head. Having a small wireless controller like this would really add to the virtual reality experience in my opinion, however this sadly does not live up to my expectations. Pairing this device up is very simple and takes just a few seconds, however you will have next to zero functionality with this device. While the controller looks and feels okay in the hand, it doesn't actually do much of anything in any games I've tested. I've tried all types of games with this and in the best case scenario I've been able to control the volume by using the analog stick, and sometimes it will bring up a mouse cursor which ruins the immersive experience that virtual reality should offer.

While I was really hoping that this would be an answer to what I think virtual reality should have, this product just falls flat on the idea. I would strongly advise anyone looking at getting into virtual reality and looking for a controller to add to the experience not bother picking this up as it is just a disappointment. I did receive this to test out and provide feedback on, but my review is honest. If you have any questions then I would be happy to answer them to the best of my abilities. To sum up what I like and dislike about this product, I'll list off the pros and cons below.

Pro's:
- It looks like it would be a nice controller.. if it worked.

Con's:
- It does not work at all for any games, aside from sometimes turning up the volume it doesn't work with any of the games I've tested and I've tried a ton of them in hopes this would work. If you want a virtual reality controller that works then I'd strongly advice taking a look at another option.
summary: I would avoid this at all costs..

reviewText:
The Defender series has been a go to case for many years for me. It is one of the few that offer a belt clip.
It adds a good bit of depth to the phone but it adds a ton of protection.
The 2-part case with an inner rigid frame surrounded by a soft outer skin makes for an ideal case.
Your phone is cradled in a cage suspended in a rubber sleeve.
The soft textured outer skin has excellent grip. You won't be dropping your phone because the case was slippery. Even when the accidental drop occurs you can rest assured that it is in one of the best cases for that on the market.
The latest generation of Defenders feature a screen protector-less design. I like this as I can now replace screen protectors as needed without having it be married to the case.
Defender does add bulk, but if you want some of the best protection there is little out there that is better.
5 stars for quality.

reviewText: Easy to apply, very durable

I had used a basic phone for many years without any problems, but my phone upgrade came up and I decided to upgrade to a smartphone. I did a lot of research and was choosing between a Samsung galaxy s4 and the HTC one m7 to save money since I didn't want to pay $200 for the newest phone. I'm so glad I went with the HTC one. As a new user to smartphones, the HTC one was easy to navigate and walked me through personalizing the phone the way I wanted it. The processor is great and quick and the screen is big and clear compared to other phones. HTC really put a lot into this phone and keep getting better with their new HTC one m8.
The phone is light and I love having the speakers on the front instead of the side or back make watching or listening to music awesome and plus, I don't need to cup my hand around it to hear anything. I use a UAG phone case which protects it well and doesn't inhibit the speakers or use of the phone at all. I wish it had a sd card slot, but 32 gigs of internal memory is a lot, but with all the online storage programs available means I hardly use any phone memory.
The android store and program I think is better than apple's store. I have a chromecast too which works great when I control it with my phone. I highly recommend this phone to anyone wanting to save money and get a great phone. I got my for 0.1 cent on amazon after amazon refunded me $50 after I had bought it for $50 and the price dropped the same day. Go amazon customer service and HTC for making an awesome user friendly phone!!

The material portion that goes against my skin is super soft. I prefer to put it over my sleeve but it doesn't itch or bother me. The seam that looks weak on some pictures is holding up well. From what I can tell, this is now one piece of material making up the entire backing (skin side) from behind the holder all the way down the strap so it won't come apart anymore. I received this armband free for my honest review.
summary: Key holder, reflective material, and holds a Zune. Nice!

My husband is a watch collector so I ordered this pack in the hope that he could use it on a few of his watches as well as the samsung gear S2.

****Positives****
+The screen covers are super easy to install. Sometimes they're impossible but this one went on without a hitch.
+It's a 6 pack! That means even if you don't read the included instructions like you should (cough cough) you (or your wife) can try again.
+This is sized perfectly for the Gear S2, but it also fit a lot of my husband's other watches.
+The screen protector is "self healing" so small scratches and nicks magically disappear. I wouldn't go at it with a knife or anything, but don't worry about normal wear and tear.

****Negatives****
-This is sized perfectly for the Gear S2- so that means it covers the touch screen portion. The edges aren't covered and this means the screen cover can peel off if it gets caught or after it's been on a while.
-The protector seems to attract fingerprints more than the screen did, which can be really annoying. I use a glasses cloth to remove them but you could use your glasses.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone looking for a good screen cover for their Samsung Gear.

They are supposed to be the fast charging USB and i have to say Im impressed! They charge both my GS4 and HTC with High speed rate. USB charging is a bit complicated which partly explains this product's mixed reviews. Here's an example: If I plug my phone into this charger it starts charging and everything is fine. If I then also plug in my iPad to the second PowerBlock jack, the iPad doesn't acknowledge the charger at all. If I then unplug the phone the iPad will display "Not Charging" which means the PowerBlock is powering the iPad but the iPad doesn't think there's enough power available to also charge the battery. But... it turn out this is all just Apple being a Steve Jobs monopoly.

If I reverse the order of things, and plug the iPad in first, and the phone second, both happily charge nicely! So the issue isn't that the Griffin PowerBlock can't deliver enough power. It's how Apple has programmed the iPad. My Android phone, regardless, is always happy with the PowerBlock.

I suspect the above weirdness is not the fault of the Griffin PowerBlock, but the way Apple implemented charging on the iPad. Apple, of course, wants you to ideally only use APPLE accessories. They don't make any money otherwise. So I suspect they've intentionally programmed  the iPad charging software to discourage use of third party accessories such as this one.
summary: Nice adapter but a few Apple glitches

reviewText:
This charging hub works VERY well. As you can see from the image, I have the following items connected, filling each of the USB ports:

iPad Air
iPhone 6 (with an Otter Box Resurgence battery case)
iPhone 5
FitBit Charge HR
Bluetooth earpiece
Jaybird Freedom BT headphones
Acqua BT speaker

There are 2x2A charging ports and 5x1A ports. You'll have to experiment as I did to determine which port works with which device.

The StarTech is handling charging each item without breaking a sweat. In fact, the ONLY negative thing I would say about this product is it requires an included a wall wort, which might make it a little challenging to pack in a suitcase when traveling.

Also included are a mounting plate and hardware for attaching the hub to another surface and two additional outlet adaptors for European and Asian outlets. Nice.

All in all, this has now become my charging station of choice.

I have used and still have Otterboxes for all of my little toys. I feel my tablets/ipads/phones are very safe inside an OtterBox. They aren't easy to take off, and they don't come apart if you drop it. The thing I don't like about OtterBox is the screen protector. I punch this out on all my cases and just make sure I've got stick on Screen Protector. The other bad thing about OtterBox is the weight they add to your device. I do wish OtterBox would put in the magnets to turn device on/off. They used to this but stopped.

If you are looking for stellar protection for your device, you can't go wrong with an OtterBox. And really, you shelled out enough money for the device you're using, you might as well shell out a bit more to put top notch protection as well.

After several months of using this product, I had to modify my review.  I have to conclude that this X-Grip  is just NOT a good solution for motorcycle riders. Fist, I am not confident that it's secure enough. On more than one occasion I noticed that after going over an unexpected bump, the phone can shift slightly upward or downward depending on the bump.  I ride a large Harley touring bike with minimal wind behind the windshield. I would be very leery of putting this on a sport bike. I also find that you have two options - You can have the upper left bumper either strike and obstruct the volume up key or the volume down key....not too fun when streaming music to your motorcycle head unit.

I am a fan of Ram products overall, but they should stop promoting this as a motorcycle solution. It isn't.  In my weeks of searching, I've concluded that other products aren't that good either. You can choose from an X grip that doesn't hold the device very snugly and obstructs your buttons,  or a pouch that causes your phone to overheat and reduce visibility on the screen.  If you search Amazon for, "ram finger grip" you'll see that lots of people seem to like this mounting solution better, but if you have a "phablet" like the Galaxy Note Series or  iPhone 6 Plus, you're out of luck because the "fingers" just don't open big enough. Maybe Ram will introduce a larger finger grip one day. Until then, I would avoid the X-Grip as a motorcycle mounting solution.  If you've found something better, I'd be very interested to know what it is.

The above experiences are based on a Galaxy Note 2 and Note 4

reviewText: For a couple of years I have used the TomTom GO 60 S TomTom GO 60 S Portable Vehicle GPS GPS and have been very happy with it, particularly regarding the traffic updates. I set it every day to and from work, for which I usually have two choices of freeways to take, and it has always routed me the best way. The battery finally gave way on my TomTom so I started checking around for a GPS that also had a 6-inch screen that would also include a dashcam, so I ordered this one made by Garmin. The dashcam feature is great unless you want a dash mount instead of a window mount. I tried several dash mount options, but since the camera lens only adjusts from side to side and not up and down, you end up with the hood of your car taking up quite a bit of the screen. Yes, you can tilt the device itself to remedy this to some degree, but after doing this, to really adjust it properly, you end up with the screen tilted downward to an unacceptable degree for viewing. I ended up using the window mount it came with, which was okay, but I do prefer a dash mount. However, even with the window mount the suction cup and the stem that connects to it was very visible on the screen, so that area is prominently visible with the video that is recorded. The main reason I returned it, though, was due to its poor traffic assistance. After turning it on, I would get a notification that it was checking for traffic information, which as stated on the screen, "may take a while". It certainly did. I was usually about a third of the way home (about ten minutes into my drive time) when it would finally kick in. By that time I had passed the point of no return for my two routing options to get home, so it was fairly useless for my purpose. Additionally, some of the directions and turn/exit/lane indicators that it provided just didn't make any sense. I did download the most recent map and software prior to using it. Note that the traffic updates were coming from the Garmin app through my cell phone. Once I loaded the Garmin app, it did an override on the HD digital traffic that it comes with that is received through the power cord, which BTW was also a bit sketchy. I ended up buying and installing a replacement battery for my TomTom. It fires right up now just as it used to and gives me the best routing option for traffic in just a minute or two compared to the long time the Garmin took to do the same thing. I also bought a separate dashcam. While I would like to have an all-in-one device, and while I could probably get used to the window mount and the less than desirable view on the screen, what I couldn't deal with was the time lag for traffic information and the occasional odd routing information. So, from my experience I give it three stars. Too bad, because it was so close, but for me it was just not quite there. Hope my experience is helpful to some degree...thanks for reading!
summary: Not quite what I hoped for.

i am trying this as i normally use a different brand *xxxx armor*

IQ shield goes on great ...
clean ALL lint off watch face
spray your hands,
spray the top of the protector
list the protector and spray the "sticky side"
put on the watch and squeegee the water out from between the protector and watch
WAIT a few minutes and squeegee again and start to "roll" the sides by pressing on them
do this a few times
WAIT overnight before putting the watch on.

you will have a seamless look on the top of your watch but you can see where the protector ends on the sides - if you look really carefully.

Hubby loves this as it won't catch as much - me? i like it fitting 100% over the glass and would rather catch it a bit and have to replace it

this is a great product either way and protects your watch - my thought is for this price you can replace it monthly and save a $$$$$ watch face.

Overall, this is a decent powerbank. I like the compact, square shape  very easy to take along on the road without feeling weighed down. Its only about 4 inches tall and weighs only 2.4 ounces, so its easy to toss in a bag without a problem.

The case is all plastic but seems well put together, with tight seams. The input and output ports are well-anchored. It also has a lanyard of sorts (a small cord with a key ring at the end) which can aid in keeping this attached to something in a bag. But, if you don't like it, it can be easily snipped off.

This offers only the basic functions. Theres no power level indicator  just one USB output port (1A) and one micro USB input port. Both are located at the top end. Theres an indicator light to show it is charging a device. The light goes out when the device is charged or the powerbank is empty. Theres also an indicator that comes on when you plug the powerbank in to charge it, and it also goes out when the powerbank is full.

Given the small capacity (2600mAh) this is strictly for low-powered devices, such as mp3 players, phones, etc. Its not at all suitable for a tablet. Even with small devices, 2600mAh doesn't go far  basically one full recharge and the powerbank will be empty.

But, when you're low on power something like this can be very handy. The small size makes it easy to take along so youll have it when needed. Its not feature-rich, but for the price, its a great value.

summary: Nice compact shape for a basic powerbank

I mean to say that the first one was a perfect fit, but broke when I fell on my right side, no fault of the product, fault of an old chair. The second one I ordered from here and didn't fit quite so perfectly. I found that moving a certain way, something would push the phone partially out of the holster side. The phone fell a couple times to the floor, but the cover on the phone side works perfectly to save the day. No scratches. What I had to do is to grab a lighter and heat the clip sides just enough to bend them by half a millimeter each. After that the fit was snug and the phone doesn't push out anymore. I would have discarded the holster if it hadn't been that I knew it could do better with the tweak. It's up to you if you want to risk it and play with fire.

The case, however, is a different story. My only and biggest complaint is this case has no textured grip whatsoever. It slides and slips with no effort. Now the designers could have done this on purpose to it can slip in and out of the pocket, and if that is the reason, they definitely did succeed at that. For me, this isn't ideal because I already determined the GN2 is too big for the pocket and I need a holster to carry the phone around

I ended up combining the BoxWave case with the Seidio holster. Perfect combo for me until one of it breaks lol
summary: Love the holster, not so much the case

reviewText: Excellent product...provides the protection I would need if I was ever to drop my phone.  Luckily for me I haven't dropped it yet.  My only complaint isn't a problem with the case but a result of the design by Motorola to locate the volume buttons so close to the middle edge of the phone.  Because of this design issue, I can't snap my phone into the holster with the volume buttons near the top of the holster because the then the holster clip would be right on the volume down button.  Would have been nice if the holster clip would have been biased a bit over so it would miss the volume buttons.
summary: Good case for the Moto X 2nd Gen

reviewText:
I really love this device after the trip to England for 2 weeks.  4 different cities including 2 sub-urban and 2 urban cities, GlobalMe performed great with fast to login and getting connected with the network. For the 1Gb package,  it was able to last for the whole trip with ~200mb left that including using google map for walking and directions, some web searching, and making phone calls to local vendors. Advise: follow some online suggestion to turn off certain features on the cell phone so it won't burn data by mistake. I connected only two devices with GlobalMe even though it supports 5 devices. More devices mean more chances of accidentally burn the data,

Pros:

  - One device for multiple locations. No local SIM required!!
  - Fast login and connections to network
  - Price for the package is great compare to international plan from mobile companies.
  - Looks great (like an iPhone except much thicker of course).

Cons:
  - Device is little bulky. Glass surfaces on both sides make it easy to crack if drop.
  - Wish there's a better user manual to come with the device
  - Price is not cheap compare with other portable wifi

Recommend: Definitely yes.

Update:

I was able to do Wi-Fi calling but found out some phone carriers will charge Wi-Fi calling for calls outside of US. Wi-Fi calling is using Wi-Fi not cellular network, why it's cost extra $$ for wi-fi calling overseas. So just beware!!
summary: Great portable and truly SIM-less wifi device

I use the vent mount, simply because it's a lot more snug and I don't have to keep placing/removing the windshield mount every time I use it. My phone also doesn't "bounce" with the vent mount, and I drive a lot of back roads with potholes. The cradle also works better with the vent mount. For some reason, Kensington has the cradle snap into place with the vent mount a lot better than the windshield mount. The Windshield mount doesn't snap it into place, causing it to bounce for people who use that. That's the only con I have.

Overall, the product works as advertised. Be aware that the vent mount is a bit difficult to install & remove, but after it's installed it's definitely very convenient for your everyday commute.
