Google Cardboard 45mm Focal Length Virtual Reality Headset - With Free NFC Tag & Headstrap (Brown)

I was very hesitant to try another 'cardboard' version of the VR headset. Admittedly I bought a cheap-o from China on my first try, but that experience (30 minutes to cut out, glue and tape together, 2 different web-sites and a YouTube video) left me nervous about trying again.

But I persevered and tried again. WOW!

The packing started out in a very nice cardboard sleeve that I had to zip open along the perforation. Then it just laid open... ready to go!

I took a moment to look all around, seeing numbers and one bit of direction that was all I needed - attach number to number (or something like that, I got excited and actually did it and now it's done!).

The only bit that was a tad confusing was the tape that I was supposed to pull off the top layer to make it stick. Confusing for about 2 seconds.

I have to say that I have gotten a lot of tech over the years and this was probably the most easy, most user-friendly, most fun build I've done it a long time. From open to downloading the Cardboard app took maybe 5 minutes, and that's because I was being careful and checking twice.

Even though I got a discount on this, I would definitely have paid full price. I paid more than this for the junky Chinese one I got! Argh!

Needless to say that I would highly recommend this item to friends, family and anyone else that wants to check out VR stuff (enemies and fr-enemies get the Chinese version!) ;-)
summary: Love it! Best/Easiest Cardboard VR I've ever seen!

I was skeptical on buying these headphones because of the size of the microphone.  I should have listened to my instincts.  The mic is too large and naturally hangs just on your neck/shoulder.  With the weight on one side, it doesn't give you the range of motion with turning your head, without the mic constantly reminding you that it's there.

The second time I used them, I took them on a 16 mile run.  It lasted approximately 1 hour, before it suddenly died (music simply stopped playing and I could not power the headphones back on).  After charging the headphones for more than 2.5 hours, the headphones still wouldn't turn back on.  It took 2 days, before I can turn them back on.  I'm assuming that there was some sort of damage because of sweat leaking into the mic... But that brings be back to my first point... The mic is terribly placed.

I primarily use these headphones for running and I thought that they would be good for running a 26.2 mile marathon.  However, I'm very discouraged at this point and don't think that it will last longer than 8 hours.

I can see these being good headphones for weight lifting and at the gym.  Aside from that, don't bother.  I'm very disappointed and wish I could have these type of headphones with no mic.
summary: Very distracting microphone.  Sweat damage on second use.  Unsatisfied.

reviewText:
This well made messenger-style bag has so many features it's hard to list them all.  It's made from soft tan canvas and chocolate imitation leather accents that look like real leather.  It's got an adjustable shoulder/across-body strap, a regular handle on top, secure snap closures on decorative straps/buckles, a large zippered main compartment that contains two more zippered compartments inside and also two cell-phone sized pockets.  The outside of the bag has two large canvas pockets with magnetic snaps.

I've used it as an overnight bag and had plenty of room for everything I needed, although it's masculine enough for a man to carry without anyone thinking he's carrying a purse.  It would be perfect as a travel carry-on bag, or for transporting books, computer equipment, or for office files.  I measured my bag and it's a little bigger than the description states - mine is 12" tall, 16" long and 6" inches deep at the base.  It expands much wider when full, and the two outside pockets give even more storage space.  The entire bag is stitched heavily and securely, and it's obviously made to last.

There's no price listed at the time I'm writing this review, but I could see paying $30-$40 for a bag like this one.

Glass screen protectors are very smooth and do not take away from the responsiveness of the touchscreen. Familiarize yourself with the items and steps I am going to lay out below. I have done so many brands of these and many brands more than once so I am going to list what one should have for the job and note missing items first.

1. Wet Cleaning Pad
2. Dry Cleaning Pad
3. Microfiber Cloth - NONE, you should have a small cloth that is new or dust free for cleaning streaks after cleaning
4. Scraper (Mainly for Tablets. Can Be Used on Phones Too.) - NONE, not really needed for a phone. Use your finger.
5. Dust Stickers (Only if You Get a Speck of Dust Before Placement)

The best place to do these is where it is mainly dust free and where the humidity is a little higher than normal. The humidity is to help keep static down and being in a dust free place helps ensure none gets on your screen before you place it. One tiny speck will raise the glass in that one spot. If that happens to you, gently take the glass up and use a fingernail or something on that dust particle and drop the glass back down. When you peel off the protective coating on the screen protector is when you will get the most static. You can do it in the kitchen or shortly after a shower but no steamy fog, just a little humid so you do not steam up the glass. Static and dust are the enemies. The whole process is really painless and takes about two minutes in a perfect world. Take your time in the first steps, if needed, and when placing the glass, get it aligned and get it down. Implementing are as follows:

1. For prepping, simply take off the case and old screen protector, if any.

2. Use the wet cleaning pad to thoroughly clean the screen, especially if your screen was naked.

3. Use the drying pad to take up excess moisture and pull up any grime.

4. The microfiber cloth should be used to take any streaks away. Look at the device at different angles in the light to be sure you do not miss any so you have a pristine screen. Also, I had one cloth from a brand leave dust as I cleaned the streaks. If that happens, have a cotton ball or something to do the job.

5. Ready to place! Have those dust stickers ready just in case a dust particle appears during this process. Peel of the film on the glass screen protector. That side goes down. Do not stop to admire it once it is off, just start to align it and get it on the device. The more time you wait, the more chances dust will have a chance to find you. Use the scraper on tablets and scraper of finger on phones while this begins to grab your screen. It is not a slow process so help it along from the middle outward.

6. BUBBLE? I generally do not get any bubbles but sometimes a small one happens. Just gently lift the edge closest to the bubble(corners are easier) and push the bubble to the part you lift. Be patient and do not lift hard. The glass will actually bend and may not grab the screen so well after.

Overall, it is real easy to do these and after doing about 30 or more of these, I follow exactly as I mention above. I even began walking friends through the process and they do it easily now. I hope it helps a lot. These glass screen protectors are smooth and if yours covers your selfie camera eye, it should be fine as I had a few like that and the images are just as clear.

reviewText: I somehow always end up dropping my iPhone so a case is a must. And this case is far more protective than most. It entirely isolates the phone, surrounding it with a barrier to water and dirt as well as to strikes on the pavement. Fairly easy to install, the only downside of the case is that there's now a bit of extra pressure necessary to activate the power and volume buttons. The mute lever is more easily controlled with the case than without it. The speakers work nicely through the barrier and the Lightning port is accessed by way of an opening door on the bottom of the case. I had no problem using standard cables and accessories through the door. There is very slight degradation of screen quality for viewing photos due to the added layer here, and occasionally I find that I need to touch images just a bit more vigorously than usual to activate or move something. Nothing you won't get used to quickly. In return, you can drop the phone into the fishtank, the snow, or onto the pavement from 6 feet and not worry. Just don't lose the little tool that comes with the case allowing the case to be removed. Getting the case on is easy without tools. Getting it off will lead to broken fingernails without the little tool. The Asphalt color is all business....no worries using this in any environment. I also tried out the Second Wind color, which remains very classy but adds a few touches of lime green around the perimeter, making the phone a little easier to find in a dark location. One final note is that the case adds a little heft, but some may notice the increased length and width; it's not a lot - perhaps 1/4" more in each direction when compared against a standard case - but if your phone is already tight in your jeans pocket, this point might annoy you a bit.
summary: Highly protective without costing too much in the way of easy access

The problem with most bluetooth headsets is very simple: they don't work. You can quibble over why they don't work: static on the connection, poor fit in the ear, or simply that neither the device user nor the person with whom they are attempting to chat with can hear each other. But the fact is that if ANYTHING interferes with the normal conversation experience, the device does not work.

Just as simply, this device works. I can hear the people I am talking with and they don't even realize that I'm talking on a bluetooth. I'm not going to forget that I have the device in my ear, but the experience is close enough to talking into the receiver that the benefits of hands-free really shine.

This is not a device that looks cool. In fact, it is kind of gangly. But let's face it: until you see supermodels rocking blueteeth(?) (i.e. never), they won't be cool. So instead of a device trying to look cool, better to have one that actually works.

For anyone cannot afford to deal with all the issues that have plagued bluetooth devices in the past and who needs to have conversations unmarred by "huhs" and "whats" and finally by "wait a minute" as you take the poorly performing device out of your ear and start the conversation over, look no further.

It works well. In this problem plagued genre, that is saying something.

Highly recommended.

Epilogue: Tragically, I washed the device with a load of clothes. Miraculously, it seemed to still work after being dried off--however, even though I could still hear what my callee was saying, they no longer could hear me. So, don't wash your bluetooth!
Works as expected.

The Good:

I really do love the feel of this screen protector. It's feels wonderful to swipe. Fingerprints aren't eliminated completely but it does very well at not showing them. When a smudge becomes noticeable a quick swipe on my shirt sleeve or pant leg and its gone.

The Bad:

Installation is a "one shot" deal. Make sure that your phone is perfectly clean (and your hands too). I think Spigen will send you a discounted replacement if you foul up installation too badly. (see their web site for details)

One minute speck of dust during installation and the bubble has never fully gone away. I opted to live with it as the feel more that makes up for it. The fact that it's down by the home button rather than in a more view area of the screen probably helps too.

The Ugly:

I quickly saw what many people mention ... fragile sides ... mine got a small chip and nearly invisible crack after only a few days after I installed it. not drops or anything just going in and out of my pant pocket. It may have had a problem sharing the pocket with my keys.

Worked for a year then stopped out of nowhere. I didn't abuse it, I merely had it plugged in, then it sat in my room when I wasn't using it. I've since had to replace it. Please buy it from somewhere else - unless you'll only need the cable for a year.

reviewText:
Made with lovers of gadgets and mobile devices in mind, this is the best solution I've seen yet.

This unit comes with two cables and a sleek carrying pouch. Despite its large size, it is very light. It feels lighter and easier to carry than the RP-PB19 (RAVPOWER 4.5 amp 16750 portable power pack). The Quick Charge feature is great for those on the go or with multiple gadgets and truly works. I plugged my Samsung Galaxy Note 4 into the QC port completely depleted to test it and was amazed to see my phone at 80% power.  From 0 to 80, on my Note 4, in 30 minutes! That's better then the manufacturer "Adaptive Fast Charging" method.

I've tested the Quick Charge on my Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, Gear S2 Classic SmartWatch, Gear 2 Neo, Galaxy S5 and Note 4, my Altec Lansing Life Jacket Speaker and iPad 2 and am happy to say all these devices were supported.

This is the best solution on the market and I highly suggest you consider it!

The Xperia phones look nice and work as well as I expected, but nightly charging required that you pry off the micro-USB flap and then snap it back on. I was worried about doing that too often causing the loss of water-proofing, so I went looking for a magnetic charging cable that would allow us to let that port stay unmolested most of the time. Since we were using cases, we didn't consider a dock: most of the docks looked like they wouldn't work with the case. This was clearly a missed opportunity for Sony, since an integrated system of case and charging dock would have been preferred.

The #1 search result for magnetic charger on Amazon is the Magnector X. Hailing from Korea, the marketing copy looks great though the price seems high. It comes in a little case with a carrying pouch, and a little nub that connects to a usb cable and then attaches to your phone. The problem? The nub is wide, so the charging pins never makes contact with your phone if your phone is in a case. So we returned it.

The E-PRANCE cable hails from China, has 7 reviews, and doesn't qualify for Amazon prime. It ships direct from Shenzhen, comes through the postal service and takes weeks to deliver. It doesn't appear to have strain relievers on the cable, which means that if you jerk it too hard, it will break. Fortunately, it's a magnetic charging cable, so pulling on the phone means that the charger will just fall off the phone, so the cable shouldn't ever be subject to huge stress. In any case, it's cheaper than the Magnector X. To my relief, the charging end is thin, and easily charges both our phones while they're in their cases. We went ahead and ordered 4 (2 at home, 1 in each car). Recommended.
summary: The winner if you put your Xperia in a case.

I've been wanting an LED desk lamp for quite a while now. And this lamp fits the bill quite nicely. The reason why I purchased this one rather than the other lamps is the overwhelming positive reviews as well as the built-in functions and the style. So here is the breakdown:

PROS

Excellent style. The glossy white is very expensive looking. The bendable joints allows a good range of motion so you can position it under tight spaces or angle it in best way you like.
4 kelvin colors. What can be best described as: white (reading), blue tint (studying), warm incandescent (relaxing), and orange incandescent (sleeping). I have been using it mostly on full blast at 'reading' and it has been awesome. On a few occasions I set it on 'relaxing' while doing graphic design and it really is easy on the eye balls and hardly noticeable in terms of distraction.
60 minute timer. I'm guessing this setting would be useful to someone that leaves the light on when going to bed. Haven't really used it but it's a nice feature to have.
Ease of set up. I didn't read the manual. Just connect the light to the base, secure both units with supplied plastic washer and it's ready to go.
No heat. This is probably the biggest reason in purchasing a LED lamp. I have actually seen traditional incandescent lamp melting away the plastic shade and even the fabric shades when left on for too long. I put my had up to the bulbs and can barely feel any heat being emitted. Which means less energy is wasted. Heat = Energy
Touch panel. All the controls are touch panel. No moving buttons or soft touch buttons to press. Awesome!
Built in USB port in the side for your smartphone.

CON

Only one draw back: the lamp can be a little wobbly at the joint where the unit is connected to the base. I thought maybe I didn't secure it well enough but as it turns out it's just wobbly. Not a deal breaker but would have liked it to be rock solid.

All in all, a wonderful LED lamp that now sits next to my iMac. My work desk is now complete.
summary: Expensive looking lamp at a good price!

I recently purchased this phone when I decided to leave Verizon Wireless to go to Cricket Wireless to save some cash on my monthly bill. I knew the new G4 was coming out in a few weeks, but all the tech reviews online said this was a great phone so there was no need to wait. Since I was moving to Cricket Wireless (which runs on the AT&T network), I bought the AT&T version at full price and activated it on Cricket.

The phone is really sleek. Even though the screen is bigger than most standard phones out there, the bezel and body of the phone are so well crafted that it doesn't feel bigger. In fact, in my hand and pocket, it feels the same size as my old Galaxy S4 which has quite a smaller screen. Although I thought the placement of the power and volume buttons on the back was odd at first, I quickly realized that made much more sense on a phone and loved them. They were just in the right place for quick adjustments. Even better, the phone has "knock on", so to turn on the display when it's on a table or in a car dock, just double tap the screen and the phone turns on. It's an amazing feature that I love.

Both the front and rear cameras are pretty good quality. It takes pictures quickly and the results are usually pretty solid. The speaker is pretty powerful, much louder than any smart phone I've used before. Battery life is not amazing but pretty decent. It seems pretty on par with any other smart phone I've used.

I would say the only negative to the phone is the software. The LG overlay and apps just feel a bit dated. Luckily that can quickly be solved by downloading alternate apps that look and feel better. I use Nova Launcher for my home screen and Textra as a text app. It does have a lot of AT&T apps on it that I'll never use, but that seems to be standard on all AT&T phones.

Overall it seems like a great phone and a very nice upgrade from my old Galaxy S4.

****6/29/2015**** - Update
I removed one star because after a month of usage, battery life isn't as great as I'd like. While standby time is great, but when I actually use the phone, it goes through the battery way too quickly. Even with the screen dimmed down as low as is tolerable, it still burns through it pretty quickly. It may be better if you're using it on AT&T and running the newest Lollipop update. Because I'm on Cricket, I'm not able to upgrade the software.
summary: Great looking and performing phone. AT&T Version works on Cricket Wireless out of the box

reviewText:
I purchased this phone back in November 2012. I got it directly from T-mobile at the time for $200 with $50 prepaid minutes. I upgraded from the T-mobile Optimus-T. This was a HUGE upgrade from what I had.

PROS:I love the screen and the controls. It is very peppy, equipped with a dual core processor. The colors are vibrant and the 1080P video recording looks great. The camera is excellent outdoors and so-so indoors. So far this has run pretty much every app I have thrown on it without a problem. I would easily buy this phone again. I love LG phones and consider them as good if not better than Samsung. My screen is much bigger than what you would find on an iPhone, but the resolution seems to be just as good (side by side).

The phone quality is excellent. It allows for 4G data, although you can specify 2G only or disable data altogether. The GPS works great. I currently use Co-Pilot for my GPS maps and GPS status for tinkering around. It also works great with Torque. I use the Bluetooth a lot and have no quarrels with it. The Bluetooth range is excellent.

The Wi-fi also works great. I use this phone without a data plan, so the wi-fi is a lifesaver when I'm at home so I can check my e-mail and browse the internet. Internet browsing on this phone is so good, thanks to a nice large screen, that I don't even use my computer anymore.

CONS: My old Optimus-T allowed me to copy apps to the SD card, saving me on my limited 200mb internal storage. The Optimus L9 does NOT let you copy programs to the external SD card, which I though it could when I bought the phone. The 2gb internal storage is much bigger than my old phone, but it fills up very fast. I wish they had either put more inside this phone or allowed transferring apps to the external SD.  I understand this is a limitation put on by the Android ICS OS and not LG.

It WILL allow you to put music, pictures, videos and other files on the external SD card, so all is not lost. You can also set up the native camera and video recorder to put files on the external SD card, saving internal storage space.

CONCLUSION: I would easily buy this phone again. The phone quality is excellent and it functions like a dream. If you need more internal storage, consider going with the LG Optimus G. You can't beat the price on this phone.
summary: Very Nice Phone For The Money

reviewText:
Just got the protector and so far, it's great.
1) It's fairly easy to apply versus other protectors I've used - helps that there a guide stickers that you can use to help guide the placement (though if you take a little too long, the glass can start to separate from the sticker due to gravity).
2) It doesn't bubble or have an edge that lifts like some other protectors will do.  Just make sure you let it settle and you smooth it out to make sure it stays on correctly.
3) The material of the protector itself is made of a good quality (heavier material) so I have confidence it will be durable.
4) The protector also has great visibility - doesn't dull the image of the phone at all.
5) The protector is also smooth and doesn't slow down functionality at all.
6) The protector also seems to resist normal daily smudging so a bit of regular wipe-down with an appropriate cleaner will help keep your screen clean.
7) The protector fits very well on screen surface and does not cover up the home button or the speaker and it also doesn't go all the way to the edge of the phone.  If you're using a case, the size is great because the protector won't end up lifting when you put the case on/off and the protector also shouldn't keep your phone from fitting into the case.  But, if you are looking for a wider surface area of coverage (protecting edge to edge), this is just something to be aware of.

reviewText:
I had two cases for my iPhone 5C and they were absolutely outstanding! They protected my phone from so many bumps and falls. Spigen did a great job with those cases so I knew I could trust then.

Skip forward a few months and I've got a new phone. I needed a phone case, I'm quite a clumsy person so my phone is prone to being dropped. I immediately came to Spigen and seen many different cases for my LG G3. I was more than happy with this this so I picked the one I wanted and waited for it to arrive!

When I received it the packaging was almost identical to the packaging of the iPhone 5C cases, professional and aesthetically pleasing. The case of course comes in two parts and they're easy to pull apart. The case features a roughly 2mm rise bezel around the screen so if you place your phone with the screen downwards there won't be any scratches due to your phone being raised ever so slightly.

The case looks absolutely stunning, I picked the gold one to match my phone and couldn't be happier! The case doesn't add much bulk and I can use the case for hours on end without getting any hand ache or any uncomfortable feeling.

The case cutouts are all in the right place and have been strategically cut. Spigen cares about their products and cares about protecting the customers devices. I have recommended spigen to quite a few friends and family members and have heard nothing but positive things from them!

All in all, the case is amazing. Protects your phone perfectly from bumps, scrapes and falls, makes your phone look amazing and doesn't add much bulk and weight to your phone. I'd recommend this to anyone who wants to protect their while making it look amazing at the same time.

Good job Spigen, you've earned my support for a long time!

I used this SIM in US, UK, Germany, Denmark, Belgium, and the Netherlands. Setting it up was pretty straightforward, though it did take about 15 minutes before it started working when I activated it in the US.

The only issue with this is that it wasn't clear that I will only get 3G when roaming outside of UK. I did get LTE when I'm in London. If the UK is your first destination, you can pick this up cheaper in the UK. 3G does work reasonably well, especially for less data intensive stuff. A couple of times I had to select a specific carrier in order for it to connect, but otherwise it's pretty painless.

I could receive SMS and phone calls, and I could make phone calls to the same country when in Europe. There doesn't seem to be any way to load more credit to it unless you have a UK bank account or credit card (I didn't try). There's an app to track data usage but it's not available if your Google account is not based in the UK.
summary: 3G (and occasionally 2G) only when roaming outside UK

There are a few reviews criticizing this product saying that nothing fits in the pocket. However, it truly does, if you're reasonable enough to accept that you might only put one credit card, one debit card and maybe a folded over $20. It's not a wallet, it's a mini-pocket for the very bare essentials you might need when running an errand and don't want to bring your whole purse or wallet. Or maybe you're out for a jog or some other activity where you don't bring your whole bag of goodies along.

The case fits the phones nicely, all the holes line up and it feels solid. I can't say I'll use it as my every day case, as I prefer something with a nice graphic and a smoother feel than when you have goodies jammed into a pocket on the back. But for quickie jaunts like I've mentioned above it's good. And it's easy enough to pop on and off so you can have a different "regular" daily case and only use it when needed.
summary: works if you're not expecting to fit your whole wallet contents inside

reviewText:
I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

First Impressions:

1. Packaging  Really nice.  I love white packaging.  It is easier to read than other colors, especially as we get older.
2. Instructions  Great  Easy to read (the print is the perfect size).
3. SuperPak i2  Weighs about 4.2 ounces and measures 3.6 x 1.9 x 0.9 inches.  The i2 is compact and is easy to transport, either in your pocket or bag.

The UNU SuperPak i2 (5000mAh) is an Apple Certified portable charger that can charge any of todays mobile devices.  The included charging cable is also very cool.  One end is USB and the other is either a micro USB or a lightning adapter.  This lets us charge the i2 using a computer or wall plug (not included) and then flip it around and charge our mobile devices.  My iPhone 6 was able to be charged twice from one charge of the i2.  That is nice, especially when traveling or out for the day.  My iPad Air 2 received a 55% charge from the i2.

The i2 is available in both black and white models.

Overall, the i2 is perfect for the everyday user that needs that extra power during the day.  For the price, you cannot go wrong.  This would make a great gift for all of your friends and family.

I have received this case few days ago and my first impression was Wow!
The package was delivered on a Clasp Brown Envelope and when I opened the envelope, I saw an attractive milky white outer box that has the picture of the case on the front and detailed instructions (make sure to read them & follow when putting your phone into the case) of how to install my Samsung S5 phone into the case. reviewText:
My phone got knocked off a counter-top and hit a tile floor screen-side down.
I had a game paused on it but the mute switch was set on 'quiet.'
When the phone hit the floor it threw the switch and music from the game started playing from the speakers... A fairly solid hit perfectly face-down.
The phone is completely undamaged. I'm naturally happy with the case.

I like the grooved diamond-pattern texture in the rubber. I did not like how the old 3GS cases lost their roughness and got smooth with wear. Hopefully this will retain better grip.

The only thing I don't like is the screen protector. It has a grain to it. The good thing about it is that it doesn't stick to the glass, but the screen doesn't look as nice, its almost impossible to read in bright sunlight, and I got along just fine with the baby-powder trick on the old 3GS cases. This is the only reason I didn't give the case 5 stars.

I'm considering pulling the screen protector out like other reviewers have mentioned and using some stick-on screen covers.
summary: iPhone4s hit tile face-first hard enough to throw the mute switch off...

reviewText: The product is great idea. The process was a bit confusing and I think the directions can be a bit more clear. The product was delivered very quickly. Packaged very well. You mean I can have iPhone quality pics and video (ooh, and slo-mo) up to 100 ft deep, for about $10? My wife and kid can do the same with their phones and I don't have to worry about their phones getting ruined either? What's not to like? I looked at sub $100 waterproof cameras with laughably bad picture quality (no video), and most of them can only go 10 ft deep or less. I thought I'd given up on the idea until I saw this. It's like I bought 3 high quality underwater cameras for half the price of one bottom of the barrel "underwater camera".

I tested in the pool for a few hours, getting acquainted with what it'll be like for a week snorkeling and beach-hopping in Maui. No issues at all. Snapping pics with the volume button while underwater takes some getting used to, but not a knock on the product at all. Pics and video were stunning. I needed the larger case for my wife's LG G3, which takes photo quality to yet another level.

I purchased this case for my new Galaxy S4 Active phone. I really like it but was always hitting the buttons on the sides of the phone as the phone case buttons are more pronounced with the case on. This is specially true with the volume up and down buttons. I read a review where someone cut these rubber extrusions down level with the rest of the case. This was very easy to do using a pair of wire cutters as snipers to just snip the buttons off of the rubber case. This helped a lot but I was still changing the volume unintentionally. So I used a small pair of sharp scissors and cut the button holes out all together leaving a hole in the rubber case where the up and down buttons are and the on off button on the right side of the case. Now I never hit these buttons by accident and I can still use the buttons pushing in through the holes in the case. This is the only reason I did not give it a Five star rating. In fact I like it so much I ordered another for my wife's phone and made the same modification per her request. We also bought clear tempered glass screen protector from the AT&T store to make our phone much more durable and less likely to be damaged. They are now like the OutterBox with the exception of the waterproof capability of the OutterBox which is not necessary with the S4 Active since they are somewhat waterproof. The OutterBox is way more clunky then these cases. So I would still recommend this case and recommend getting a protective cover for your screen.

UPDATE: After owning this case for several months I have found that removing the phone from the case is quite a chore. For this reason I lowered my rating from 4 stars to 3 and if I had it to do over I would have just purchased the Outterbox case which already has the clear cover and easily disconnects from the belt holder.
summary: Nice Case but there are better

If your not use to The Huawei Nexus 6P then your in for a shock along with all the great features comes the side of this phone and my hands are big.

Inside the box is the phone, one USB-C to USB-C cable and Charger and one very short USB to USB-C cable, also one cardboard instructions sheet, booklet in 3 languages and a key, now if you're like me and never used that tech before then its time for some homework.

This phone uses USB-C. USB-C is a faster data and power rate cable the end is much smaller that your regular USB connector, It won't work with your Standard USB 2.0 or 3.0 slots, it does come with one "Short" USB 3.0 to USB-C cable which is backwards compatible with a USB 2.0 slot but charging time is waaaaaay slow. so If you can use a 3.0 slot with the USB-C cable then use that. In the mean time use the wall charger as often as possible.  Battery time is amazing one charge lasted me about 11 hours and i still had half he battery left.

On to the nano sim. What's that you say? Nano? yes, its much smaller than your regular micro sim card, in the box came a circle with a pin on the end to open the card slot on the side, mine was so easy to install. T-moble wanted to charge me 20.00 for a nano sim, but you can buy one on here for 5 bucks so save your money.

Updating was so fast compared to my other phones, this phone is a true google phone so updates were done though a WiFi connection with a full battery and it took a few minutes to update. Once that was done, it was time to download my previous apps, because of the large amounts of space, mine is the 64 gig version, but in retrospect, it might have been better to spend the extra money for 128 gigs, my previous phone only had 8 gig and with the update to lollipop filled my phones memory by half.

This phone was so easy to work with, and because everything went though "Big Brother" Google all of my "everything's" was there so it was like moving into a bigger house with all my furniture inside. Amazing. So with the update on marshmallow and app download it took up about 3.5 gigs. so bye bye memory hello big phone and better performance.

So far, so good. Stay tuned folks. Lets see if all this hype is bulls***.

UPDATE: 5/9/2018 Its been almost two years since i got this phone, for a Google flagship phone it's had its ups and down, Google has introduced two phones since then the Pixel and the Pixel XL and the Pixel 2 and you guessed it the Pixel 2 XL and are about to give those phones a run for its money. Personally those are the same phone with differnt processors and memory. That's just my educated Opinon like faux news. I've keep in touch with other Nexus 6P owners on Reddit r/nexus6p, i've had no major issues, nothing fell off i've changed cases and the shielding on the face of this phone and WOW nothing has happen so far.
I use this phone for everything from news and info, To games and VR, to shopping and porn, Everything. I get about 6 hours of good battery life, with light use. I've had 3 major updates from Kit Kat to Marshmellow and now Orieo, no bootloops so far. There was this time when the FBI put out a warning about Chinese spy's, once again hype, the mounting bullshit is amazing.

Its still fast and appart from some minor hickups that was corrected by battery discharged and a full restart didn't correct this phone is a monster. Don't let anyone fool you this is the go to phone when you want solid hardward and great software. My last phone came from Blu it lasted less than a year. If you do buy this phone keep your updates going don't mess with the OS and keep this phone away from moisture.

I'm keeping the phone till it dies, More update to follow.
summary: Nexus 6P its been two years so what do i think of this wonderful phone?

reviewText: Steepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Charger provides power for two devices at the same time. One device can be charged through built-in micro USB adapter, the second through a regular USB charging cable (not included). Each port provides 1A of power, the total combined current output for devices connected to this power adapter is 2.0A MAX. I tested Steepower 12W / 2.1A Dual-Port Car Charger with Nexus 7 Tablet (JellyBean 4.3) and Samsung Galaxy Nexus cell phone (JellyBean 4.2.2). I tested each on both ports, as well as both devices at the same time. The results were different on each port and now I plug them in only in one configuration which tested best. You will find the results of my tests in the table below. I own several car chargers and run the same set on tests on each of them, so they can be compared to each other using "apples to apples" comparison. This set of tests allows me to provide unbiased results as the numbers speak for the performance of each unit. My methodology is to charge each mobile device on each port of the unit for 10 minutes and measuring how much each unit was charge in that 10 minute period. Each line in the table below represents a separate 10 minute test. I use Battery App by Elvison to determine how each device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge. To test this Steepower car charger I ran my 10 minute test on Nexus 7 and Galaxy Nexus phone on each of the 2 ports as well as both devices at the same time. I also tested using both a both a data cable and a charging cable as I noticed that Nexus 7 did not charge at all with a data cable (this is not the case with all car chargers). The data cable was able to charge the phone so the cable itself is functional. A quick note about the difference between a power cable and a data cable: Charging cables short the two data connections together (rendering them useless for data transfer), but this fools devices to see them as an AC power connection, and thus accept the higher current of the charging source. This car charger makes a good contact with the car's power port. It did not wobble or got dislodged during our weekend trip on a number of unpaved roads when it was used to power Nexus 7 serving as a GPS. Its weight is 2.1 oz, it is 3.375" long, and front of the plug is 1.125" in diameter. The coiled cable is 22" (unstretched). Nexus 7 Tablet -------------- Built in cable -- AC ............. 2% change in charge in 10 minutes Charging cable -- AC ............. 3% change in charge in 10 minutes Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone -------------------------- Built in cable -- AC ............. 6% change in charge in 10 minutes Charging cable -- AC ............. 4% change in charge in 10 minutes Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone and Nexus 7 Tablet at the same time -------------------------- Built in cable -- AC ............. 5% change in charge in 10 minutes (Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone) Charging cable -- AC ............. 4% change in charge in 10 minutes (Nexus 7 Tablet) Key finding: ------------------ This car charger worked very well. The phone worked best using the built-in cable and the tablet worked best using the charging cable. Since I did not expect the "best" port to be different between the two I re-run my tests several times and the results remained consistent. I received this charger from the manufacturer for testing and writing a review, be it positive or negative. reviewText:
This is my second update to an earlier review and I just ordered a second unit after my unreasonably abusive use of the first one for about a year.  I have  dropped the wallet/phone (including on concrete sidewalk) an unforgivable number of times and have NEVER managed to damage my iPhone in the wallet. I have been using it during domestic and international travel and have built long term solid experience to continue recommending it to all my associates and friends who are considering, or already have, an iPhone 6Plus.  The combination has proven terrific for me and, aside from size of the currency pocket being a tiny bit too small for US bills, I find little fault with it. Stitching seems excellent and it has held up extremely well.
Before I purchased the wallet, I was concerned that some reviewers claimed to have experienced erasure of credit card magstripe data from the magnetic latch.  However, I have been carrying five credit/debit cards, my business NFC entry card, and my driver's license (see picture) with no effect on their magnetic data transfer in merchant transactions. (I do try to keep the cards with the magstripe oriented away from the latch, but have not always remembered to do so.)
(Note that the fourteen U.S. bills are a pretty tight squeeze and I fold over one end.)
I am a continuing strong user/advocate of this product and will continue to help them sell more!
summary: Second purchase of a product that I reach for innuerable times every day.

reviewText:
I've used this on my Samsung Galaxy Nexus and my dads LG Optimus G, and it works great. It's very fun, fast and easy to just plug in and view pictures and videos from a trip. It's also VERY cool to operate your touch screen phone and see it mirrored on the big screen.

I even used it on my Galaxy Nexus when visiting family to stream movies and TV shows in 720p from my home PC to their HDTV with the app Plex.

You do need an HDMI cable to connect it to the TV or receiver, and It does also need power from a standard micro-usb power adapter (I've never tried it with anything offering less than 1 amp). I've heard some TVs and accessories are starting to offer power over HDMI for MHL stuff like this, so this may not be the case for you depending on the equipment.

I ordered two of these infuser water bottles so I could always have one clean and available for use.  I have to admit I was a bit skeptical about the reviews I read but overall they were the best ones I found online so I gave these bottles a chance.  I received them today and even though I haven't used them yet, I'm very happy with them.  The design is contemporary and clean.  The lid truly is no-leak, as I filled both bottles with water and inverted them for several minutes to see if there was any leakage.  I shook one vigorously and still, no leaks.

I love the simple design that includes a spout or mouthpiece that allows the user to drink from a smaller opening than from the entire bottle, as some are designed.  I also like the flip-top lid that snaps securely in place.  The infuser basket snaps on and off easily, allowing for easy access to put fruit in and also easy access for cleaning.

I have recently started eating a lot more fruits and vegetables s(see my review on the Nutribullet) and these infuser water bottles fit right in with my desire to consume healthier, less processed food and drink.  All I will have to do is cut some fruit or vegetables into small pieces, put them in the basket, and voila--cold, refreshing water with the taste of cucumbers...or strawberries...or apple cinnamon... the possibilities are endless!
summary: So glad I purchased two of these!

reviewText:
This is my 2nd one that I ordered. While it's not quite perfect, it's about as close as any case I've tried (and I've tried TONS).

It's slim. One of the qualities of the iphone 4 I like is it's slim form factor. A lot of the cases out there add so much bulk that I may as well be carrying around a home phone with wall charger attached. This one keeps my iphone looking like an iphone in all respects. It has just enough of a lip around the front that it keeps the glass from contacting when you set/drop it on the floor, but it doesn't impede full use of the touchscreen. A lot of cases i've used/tried would take up a decent chunk of that slim border of glass on the side between the edge and the screen. It would not allow me to actually touch and use the edges of the iphone! this one clips to the metal band, not around the glass, so it's fully open :-)

One of my favorite aspects: they have scalloped out the back end of the case where the volume and mute buttons are. It's one of those things that you realize after you've had a case like this that you know you couldn't go back to having it any other way. It's nice because when you're using the phone, you don't have to poke your fingers IN to where the buttons are, they're easily reachable and activated but sneaking your finger/thumb around from the back end, which is the end you come from to use the buttons anyhow. It's a nice touch.

The one knock I have against it is that while it has what they call a "velvet soft finish," I wish it was a bit grippier. It has SOME tac to it, but I'd like it to be just ever so slightly "rubberier." I've only come across one other case that was closer to the grip I like which was the incase slider IN RED, even every other color of that case line is just as slick as this case, for some reason the RED incase slider has the most tac of any case I've felt.

Anyhow, despite that one knock, it's otherwise the perfect case for me!
Wife loves it so I am happy

I really like that the screen has a hole farr the notification LED AND the buttons at the bottom... But the buttons are really difficult to line up, and you only get one shot.  I was a little off, but I'll live.  Also, I wish the pack came with a microfiber cloth.

This 11000 mAh has proven itself to be a good charger ably handling our cell phones, doing fine with an iPad4, but is challenged by the iPad Pro 12.9". I consulted with the owner who was very prompt at getting back to me and also very helpful. He explained the battery in the bigger iPad Pro is over 10,300 mAh and the Impower Charger is 11,000. Thus, it will do it, but he suggested some good options:

1) Make sure the Impower is fully charged.
2) Don't let the iPad Pro 12.9" go below 25% before I charge it.
3) It would be better if the applications are shut down and not to use it when charging. This is because if using it, it will draw juice and the battery is large making it more difficult to charge it.

Thus the optimal way to use the Impower with such a huge device is to either shut it down or at least close all the applications and wait for it to recharge. This has worked, though it does take longer to get to a full charge which of course is expected.

The reality is, I don't lug my iPad Pro around just anywhere and expect to have to plug it into a portable charger. It generally keeps a long charge anyway. Normally, electric is available and it gets plugged in when necessary and charged; though it is good to know in a pinch I can use this portable charger for it.

This charger was obtained so that I could use it for my iPhone when needed which has been known to go down and leave me in a lurch. I also have an older iPad4 and the Impower has charged that just fine.

The unit itself charges up quite quickly and I rather like the blue light that comes on when the button is pressed and shows the progress of charging. The unit as two USB ports on it and they can both be used at the same time. It is equipped with a short unique cable that is also equipped with adapters for various devices.

When this arrives to protect it from scratches, it has two pieces of film on it. One on the top and one on the bottom. These are easy to remove. On the top, there is also a tight fitting piece of plastic to keep the area in good condition. This plastic on the top requires a little bit of probing with one's fingernail to work it up just a touch and then it will easily peel off. Once all the film and plastic is off a very shiny black finish is revealed and is truly like a piano finish. It is very nice looking.

The unit is a bit heavier because of the bigger battery. I believe the web page states it is 9.3 ounces. It is heavier than some portable chargers but it also has a hefty battery in it too. There is a pretty velvet bag included in which the unit can be placed along with the cable. This bag is equipped with fancy well-made drawstrings that have a small bead on each end. This is a nice looking bag and is well made and doubles as a way of wiping the fingerprints off that nice piano finish when needed. I am satisfied with the unit for the purposes I intend to use it for.

I won't lie; I am normally NOT a fan of the tempered glass screen protectors. My klutzy friends swear by them but I seem to have no luck! They seem to be great for those who are accident prone but I rarely drop my phone and the 2 tempered glass screen protectors that I previously purchased had pretty large cracks after 2-3 weeks of use! I figured, what could it hurt to try another? Boy, am I glad that I did!

I really like this tempered glass screen protector from Romsa! It is thinner than my other failed tempered glass screen protectors (that may be the "secret" to why it's still working!)I do like how much suface area the screen protector covers; I know how hard this is to find!

It was also super easy to apply although at this point, I am a pro at screen protector application. I did use my own scotch tape, as I find it easier to use the smaller tape when applying (i seriously have applied probably 35-40 screen protectors at this point!) After 3 1/2 weeks of use, I am proud to say that there are no scratches or cracks (YAY!)

This is definitely the screen protector to buy if you're looking for a fingerprint, smudge and scratch resistant tempered glass screen protector! It is LITERALLY the only one that has worked for me! I also love the fact that they offer a replacement IF it ever breaks or scratches. It's so much easier to buy knowing that if this does "fail," I'll be getting a new one free of charge.

reviewText: Love it!

This case looks fine on my Black iP7 but is sticking to the back of my spouse's Jet Black iP7.  I suspect this is what people are reporting as air "bubbles".  As one might expect the two very smooth surfaces (the inside the case and the back of the Jet Black phone) adhere in spots.  If it did it uniformly it would actually be good since the gloss of the phone is obvious when the adhesion squeezes out the air space but the back of the case is too rigid to conform to the (likely) perfectly flat phone back so it just looks blotchy.

We did let the case sit after removing the inner film and the adhesions are quite small but sadly very obvious.
summary: Decent case but it sticks to the back of a Jet Black iPhone.

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this phone. I read a lot of reviews before I bought it and they seemed to vary between people who thought it was amazing (the majority) and others who saw it as a dud. One thing I did notice is that the positive reviews seemed to come from people who'd only owned it a couple of days whereas the negatives were coming from longer term users.

For that reason I decided to leave it a while before writing a review so I could get a picture of how it really performed in the day-to-day environment. My initial reaction was firmly in the "Wow!" camp. There's a lot to love about this phone: the impossibly thin form factor, the gorgeous 720p AMOLED screen (more than enough resolution at this screen size), even the little Star Trekky blip noises it makes when you input commands. I felt like I'd been transported into the 24th century compared to my previous phone, a first gen Moto G (which never missed a beat and is still in use today BTW).

After a few weeks use I started to notice some foibles. The relatively anemic, in use, battery life I could live with because I work from home a lot and I have chargers in my car etc. but things like the weak GPS locking were a pain compared to the boring reliability of the Moto G. Again, also while navigating with Waze, after about an hour or so it would constantly give up and reset, as if it had absorbed too much data and just couldn't go on. Kinda like a stick-thin super model refusing to eat all the way through a 32 ounce T-Bone steak.

The last straw though was when it started dropping calls. I have a friend whom I call most days and we usually chat for half an hour to forty five minutes just passing the time. One day I called her cellphone and the call just kept cutting out. The time was still running on the dailler but we neither could hear each other. At first I thought it was her annoying habit of leaving her phone on "make calls over wifi where available" mode (I don't know why she does this as she has unlimited minutes but maybe she thinks wifi calls are even more "free"?). Anyhow I asked if she wouldn't mind switching that out and I redialed her, cellular to cellular. Same thing happened. Now she does live in a sketchy signal area near the beach so I tried once more, this time to her landline. Same thing again, not very encouraging. I rebooted the phone and it worked fine for a few more days and then with the dropped calls again firstly with her, then to another friend's landline, then to yet another friend's cell.

At this point I realized I had to send it back. That was kind of like breaking up with the world's most gorgeous babe because you could no longer ignore the fact that they're clinically insane. But, seriously, I'm in the rental property business and I need people to be able to contact me 24/7 if the need arises. It rarely happens but I need to be there when it does. I can't have a phone that keeps cutting out when people are trying to convey important, maybe life-threatening information.

I logged on to return the phone only to realize I'd passed the return date by one day. Even so, I placed a mercy call to Amazon explaining my situation and that I would definitely be buying another phone from them and they agreed to accept the return in exchange for a gift card credit which was fine by me.

I've already ordered a replacement, the larger Blu Vivo XL. I didn't really want such a big phone. I already have a Samsung Tab S 8.4 tablet with AMOLED screen. I was really looking for something that could translate that experience into a smaller more portable form. Set up with the same apps and screen savers etc. the two really did look like mother-ship and shuttle craft. The XL is getting so close to the tablet in size that it almost makes one of them redundant. That would most likely be the tablet as I, obviously, can't make calls from it.

That said I still need a phone. I'm thinking that considering the GPS and call drop problems, maybe it's something antenna related? Maybe it's really hard to pack all those electronics into such a small form without shielding and interference issues?

Either way, I sent it back.

Farewell you beautiful thing and don't forget to take your meds!

When I review screen protectors, I take into consideration two main things:

1. The best device screen protectors are made from durable material that will protect your screen from more than just day-to-day bumps and scratches. Whether the screen protector is thick or thin, it should be hard and scratchproof. It should also resist fingerprints and germs.

2. The design of the device screen protector is almost as important as its durability. If it peels up, collects dirt around the edges, gets in the way of your device case or interferes with how your finger interacts with the screen, it probably won't last long on your device. The best screen protectors for models are smooth under your finger, responds to your touch and doesn't leave you feeling like your finger is floating above the screen  regardless of how thick it is. It also comes with a cleaning cloth to help you get all the fingerprints, oil and dust off your screen before you apply the device screen protector.

I am happy to say that this screen protector pack has met them! I am very happy with the fit, quality, and form of it! Overall, I do recommend this screen protector if you are looking the market for a new one.

Disclosure: As a fellow Amazon buyer, I have always researched items before spending hard earned money on purchases, and now I am able to test items and present my honest and unbiased reviews to assist others in making (or avoiding) purchases. I purchased this product at a discount or for free in exchange for my honest review. I hope the information I presented helps you make an informed decision! Thanks!

Everyone is using their phones and tablets so heavily these days that the batteries simply cannot keep up. We have amazing apps and programs that help us complete tasks efficiently and sinc up on our devices, allow us to keep up with friends and family and so on. All of this saps the battery of our phone in addition to the way it slows with age. Portable chargers are a must anymore. This 5000mAh from Aukey is a nice option. The cylindrical shape is easy to hold and the finish is nice. The pink color is really cute. I noticed it could be unscrewed at either end, but could not see any purpose for that.

The one thing that would make it a five star, and I feel this way about all external batteries now that I know it's an option, is to have a built in cable/connection.  It can be a hassle to keep the charging cable together with the charger, getting tangled in your bag and so on. It's just more convenient to have it connected! I would love to see that feature in the future. Otherwise it's a great item and the price is super reasonable.. The variety of colors make it convenient for families also, assigning each person a color. What do you think?
